number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												I don't often post reviews on Steam but Shovel Knight is blowing me away so much that I am making an exception. This game was billed as a throwback to the NES era and it definitely succeeds in giving you that nostalgic feeling but it also ends up being way better than all the games that inspired it.The graphics, levels and characters have so much charm and I was constantly surprised at how many memorable moments there are throughout the campaigns.There is a lot of replay value here since there are many ways to play in terms of how difficult you want the game to be. There is a new game+ of course but also other ways to adjust your experience by choosing to power up your health or use checkpoints in levels or skip those both completely. On top of that there are three additional campaigns after you finish the main Shovel Knight quest (two available now and one more to be released in the future).If you have even a passing interest in NES or SNES 2D sidescrollers, then I recommend this game without hesitation. I haven't played a game that I've personally enjoyed as much this since Super Mario Galaxy.Shovel Knight is now one of my top 10 favourite games of all time and I hope others can find the same joy that I have when I'm playing it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20
												I'm gonna keep this short. I promise. I've only started playing this game game properly for around a week now, since the Game Grumps started playing the expansion. I have completed the Shovel Knight campaign and the Spetre Knight one, and I can honestly say that this is one of the best games I have ever played! The gameplay is difficult and can frustrate you at times, but you keep going as you can feel improvement, unlike some games I've played (Dark Souls) which make me feel like I'm not getting any better. The gameplay mixes the aesthetic of a retro game with the playabilty and user-friendly feel of a modern day platformer, which is a hard mix which I feel they have nailed!THE STORY, I didn't go into this game expecting much in the way of a storyline, but I was wrong! I will not spoil any of it. The story is rich and full, the writers behind this game are excellent at creating a well-rounded immersive storyline, which is told through the game perfectly. Furthermore, the Spectre Knight campaign adds an amazing level of depth to the story. IF YOU HAVE PLAYED THE FIRST CAMPAIGN, YOU NEED TO PLAY SPECTRE KNIGHT! It adds a level of knowledge of many characters that thickens the storyline and revealing more than before.All in all, I 100% reccomend this game to anyone. I owned it for around a year before I played it properly, so my advise would be to just DO IT!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Some people would say this is a game in the mindset of the infamous and widely hated "Zelda 2: The Adventure of Link". And they would not be wrong. But ♥♥♥♥ that, nobody played this nowadays. So i might as well give you a whiff you can relate to, aye?This games is what happens when take a megaman game, take away the gun and replace it with a melee weapon. Add the pogostick jump from Duck Tales and the subweapons from castlevania and voilá, you have Shovel Knight.Theres been around a ♥♥♥♥load of ancient hipster retro games lately. Except this one here is gud. It has authentic 8 bit pixel art, smooth sountrack from the original sound composer of megaman I and II and a pleasantly scaled difficulty curve.Its not as hard as other games though, but i guess thats one of its strengh. Its as hard as you need it to as you need it to be. And this doesnt hold you back from wanting to play it again. And again.The feats add a nice taste at alternative playstyles, nothing short to say about the ramped up Newgame + Mode. And the developers made high promises of adding additional free content later.The one thing im missing out on thought is a scoreboard for clearing time and treasure, this needs to be added.Nice game overall. Worth your time and money. And its cheaper than some packs of beer. 15 Euros is an easy investment. So Wutsha waitin for, get shovelin' boyo. The dirt is strong within you.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I played this game for numerous hours on a friends WiiU and was absolutely delighted when I realized it was available on PC.By far the best platformer I played, and I've played a bunch of them. It has that cozy 8-bit feel but also has things like awesome lighting effects (for a game with a 8-bit design, there is), a very neat difficulty curve (sometimes rather challengeing, but never smash-my-keyboard-to-death-hard, except in challenge mode, but that's like Dark Souls 8-bit edition. Don't go there.) the story is entertaining (not to mention the numerous puns....), and the experience in all is very well held toghether. Also. The soundtrack. This is a GREAT game soundtrack. I recommend everyone that ever enjoyed a platformer to at least give it a chance. You probably won't regret it!

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												This game is a perfect example of why I do not like the recent glut of procedurally-generated games.The level crafting is so tight, and each level is designed with care.  Real work and skill went into making this game, and it shows.  There is little that can compare to the rush the game gives me when I finally beat a level without dying, getting past  surprisingly intelligent enemies and deviously-placed traps and beating the boss.That doesn't even mention the tight controls, the fantastic chiptune music, the graphics that so effortlessly mimic classic NES games while using modern tricks and pallets.  This is just a fantastic game.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												All my life I've identified as a demi shovel.When I was a young lad all the other boys played with trucks or soldiers, but I just wanted to play with a shovel. Every year on my birthday and christmas I would ask for a shovel. It didn't even have to be that nice, a 99 cent plastic one would do, but no. My parents would not allow me to carry out my forbidden love. Later on as a teenager I made a deal with a friend. I went to his house and gave him all of my tooth fairy money in exchange for his shovel. In that moment... I was euphoric. No more longing. No more begging. I had everything I ever wanted right there in my hands. I felt an overwhelming series of emotions: pride, guilt, happiness, worry. I thought I could hide my precious.I tried everywhere: the yard, my closet, the neighbors yard, but my parents found it. They found it and they broke it and burned it in front of me. IN FRONT OF ME.Those were the bitterest tears I've ever wept.I was grounded for 3 months but I didn't care anymore. My spirit was broken. It was that night I realized I could go on no longer. I ran away, and started dancing for tips on street corners. Sleeping with thugs, jumping from town to town. It was a horrible life, but eventually I gained enough money to buy my own shovel, and I started my own hole digging service. I didn't care if I was dirt poor (no pun intended).... I was happy.Well the years flew by, and eventually I found a woman, started a family, and got a nice job. But there was a severe price to being a father. I just couldn't keep up my shovel obsession at that point. My wife threatened to kick me out of the house, because the kids were so so scared of my shovel collection and how much time I spent with it. They accused me of not even knowing their names.I sold them. 600 dollars worth of shovels.That was 5 years ago, and I'm over it now, after months of therapy. But the other day, my 10 year old asked me to buy him a game on steam."Another call of battlefield piece of crap", I muttered to myself.I saw shovel in the title and passed out.I woke up 3 days later, staring at the hospital ceiling. It was night, and I was alone. I didn't know who I was, or where I was. I looked over and saw a picture of a small child. I wondered why it was there for a while until I realized he was my son. As I started remembering everything and everyone, one thought became dominant in my mind: shovel knight.I jumped out of bed and started looking for a way out. I realized I was only a few stories up, so I made a rope out of the sheets and climbed out. I hitched a ride back to my house, not caring who was driving or what would happen, desperate to lay my hands on that shovel game once and for all. As soon as I got home I bought the game and began playing it, and I just want to thank the developers for this masterpiece. I can't express my gratitude to them. Sure, the gameplay is fun, the music is great, the characters and enemies interesting... but what sells the game is that iconic blue shovel. I can know slay dragons with a shovel. I can defeat evil bosses and conquer obstacles. I know live in a world that revolves around shovels. This game has empowered me as a demi shovel in a way that nothing ever has before.10/10

												Some people would say this is a game in the mindset of the infamous and widely hated "Zelda 2: The Adventure of Link". And they would not be wrong. But ♥♥♥♥ that, nobody played this nowadays. So i might as well give you a whiff you can relate to, aye?This games is what happens when take a megaman game, take away the gun and replace it with a melee weapon. Add the pogostick jump from Duck Tales and the subweapons from castlevania and voilá, you have Shovel Knight.Theres been around a ♥♥♥♥load of ancient hipster retro games lately. Except this one here is gud. It has authentic 8 bit pixel art, smooth sountrack from the original sound composer of megaman I and II and a pleasantly scaled difficulty curve.Its not as hard as other games though, but i guess thats one of its strengh. Its as hard as you need it to as you need it to be. And this doesnt hold you back from wanting to play it again. And again.The feats add a nice taste at alternative playstyles, nothing short to say about the ramped up Newgame + Mode. And the developers made high promises of adding additional free content later.The one thing im missing out on thought is a scoreboard for clearing time and treasure, this needs to be added.Nice game overall. Worth your time and money. And its cheaper than some packs of beer. 15 Euros is an easy investment. So Wutsha waitin for, get shovelin' boyo. The dirt is strong within you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Anyone who's grown up with a NES and/or played any of the Capcom/Konami/Nintendo (etc.. I won't go through a whole list) games at the height of their greatness should get this game. This game is worth it at full price and if the creators make another I'll be there to support it at release.Tight simple controls like you would have on the NES, fantastic music, fun levels with secrets, random humour...It plays something like a Megaman/Mario/Zelda2 -ish conglomerate.It's just the perfect homage to the classic greats, while still creating its own identity. The creators put a lot of love and detail into this one. I can't recommend it higher for a game of its genre.Rated 8/8 bits.**Goatician :)PLAGUE OF SHADHOWS UPDATE:If you thought Shovel Knight was hard before (I didn't -- full achievements), then Plague Knight's campaign will soon change that.Plague Knight controls a LOT more awkwardly, with less HP, more knockback (almost strictly worse), has somewhat awkward attack patterns, etc... Initially.It's one of those risk/reward things, since after I got the hang of him, I was able to pretty much fly around the map taking out enemies with precision. Mind you, this won't be easy at first, since the number of times I shot myself into spikes, or just missed/slightly overshot a platform, bumped into an enemy to my doom, pressed the wrong sequence of buttons to stop myself from falling were many. But the pay-off is very worth it -- for example, going back to fighting Spectre Knight (?.. the ghost one), he initially mopped the floor with me, but the second time around I was flying all around him, dodging his attacks/hitting him from safe angles..All plague-knight levels are tweaked, and some include secret passages for a slightly more difficult path for (a something). The bosses play identically, however, since your movement style and attack patterns are completely different this changes things up in a nice way. This should not come as a spoiler (you had to have predicted it) but when you fight shovel knight himself, it is just great to see how they gave his boss music the epic boss fight theme that matched the happy tune of the intro level/shovel knight theme.It is also interesting how they changed to world so you see it from the eyes of this villain (misunderstood?). The story is again mostly bare-bones just like how shovel knight tried to emulate the NES games of glory.New Challenge Maps: There are also some legitimately difficult challenge maps which are fun little side missions. I hope they eventually release the exclusives for PC.Overall, I hope there are more expansions (free or not), or sequels. Plague knight has been a great addition to the game (again, if you find it way too hard, stick with it, because once you figure him out it is a *lot* more fun).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												“Shovel Knight” is an old-school platformer that’s very heavily inspired by classic titles from the NES days. Taking bits and pieces from various classics including “Ducktales” of all things, it combines many older game design philosophies to deliver a truly retro experience. It was developed by Yacht Club Games after a highly successful kickstarter campaign which managed to raise over $300,000.In the past few years of gaming, there have been countless attempts to emulate the feel of older games — everything from NES-era graphics to limited soundtracks based on the hardware inside older machines. Unfortunately, many of the developers have failed at delivering a quality retro experience. Whether it’s due to dodgy controls, boring gameplay, or bad design in terms of how the game functions, many retro titles don’t succeed in bringing the experience across to the player.“Shovel Knight” is not one of these games. From the fantastic soundtrack to the solid and enjoyable gameplay, it actually nails the retro feel right on the head. Genuinely challenging level design and secrets abound make the game feel right at home on an older console. Not to mention, the game refuses to hold your hand throughout, so for anyone planning on picking up the game, we suggest picking up the mantra many players of the “Souls” series did: Get good or die trying.As for the actual gameplay, it borrows bits and pieces from various games. The shovel can be used as a standard sword, as well as to pogo-bounce off of enemies. This makes boss fights a very enjoyable and unique experience, as you can juggle between trying to pogo for lots of damage and avoid attacks when on the ground. In addition to the basic shovel, there’s also plenty of sub-weapons that use magic to activate. They can also have a wide variety of effects, such as being temporarily invincible, to throwing around fire, and even just straight up punching whatever unfortunate soul is nearby.The combat is tight, but the level design shines too. They’re dense with things to do and see, and of course there are lots of enemies to fight. Secrets abound in practically every level so players with a keen eye can find themselves rather rich early on. This adds to repeat playthroughs as learning where things are hidden can radically change the gameplay experience from one run to the next.Ultimately though, “Shovel Knight” is at its core a game of risk and reward. While it’s easy to get a hold of thousands in gold, it’s not as easy to keep it — every death drops three bags of gold based on how much is currently possessed. Similar to the “Souls” games, dying before recovering the bags of gold drops another set of bags and deletes the old one. Unfortunately there’s no way around it. Dying is much more painful than any life system could bring across in a game with save files, especially considering some of the items and upgrades require multiple thousands in gold.With great and responsive combat, combined with tight level design filled with reasons to explore, it’s hard to not see “Shovel Knight” as a proper classic title. The phenomenal soundtrack punctuates the exploration and the boss fights, and the tension of having to get money back without losing more of it from the ever-so-lovely bottomless pit deaths is closer to traditional gaming than most attempts. Fortunately, it’s not held back by its desire to be a classic title, and retains the quality to be expected from a modern 2D platformer release.4/5

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												A throwback to 2D platformers from the 80s/early 90s. Shovel Knight is highly reminiscent to Megaman, but it's actually a bit more forgiving than some of the games found in that series. I'm not saying Shovel Knight is simple, there are difficult parts in certain levels, but everything is doable. Besides the typical gameplay from a 2D platformer, the game's music is awesome. It's actually one of the main reasons why this game is so beloved. The main campaign isn't too long, but it's also not too short. Though I enjoy the idea of free DLC, this game's DLC didn't really interest me. I played as Plague Knight for 30-40 minutes and he felt way too clunky compared to Shovel Knight. Maybe I'm just not used to it yet, but I have no interest in playing as Plague Knight. I don't speak for everyone, but based on what I experienced, the DLC is a pass when it comes to gameplay. Overall, I enjoyed the main game very much and I definitely recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												What can be said about Shovel Knight that hasn't already been said by countless fans and reviewers? Shovel Knight is a retro action-platformer with RPG elements and an excellent soundtrack - as well as a great sense of humor. The game features classic elements, borrowing from games like Legend of Zelda: The Adventure of Link. Mega Man, Super Mario Brothers, and Castlevania. The game is difficult. But in all the proper ways that make retro games good. Never did I feel the game was unfair or trying to hard to be difficult for the sake of being difficult. Where most "Retro Style" games these days aim for a ridiculous level of frustration and difficulty, Shovel Knight focuses on making a good, challenging, and entertaining game that's fun to play. Plenty of replay value thanks to achievements being present that actually have some challenge to them (Don't get hit for a whole level, don't die for the entire game. Beat the game without buying any special weapons or items...etc.) So there's many ways to play, as well as the ability to choose what direction you want to go in on the world map. (Bosses and levels come in sets but the order you take them in is entirely up to you.) The game is designed well and the visuals and sound are fantastic. I recommend turning up the excellent soundtrack and enjoying what is destined to be considered a modern classic. 10 out of 10. No regrets.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Duck Tales meets Megaman meets Castlevania with a Mario 3 overworld. What isn't to love?I mean honestly, if the above doesn't sound good to you, then this game probably isn't for you.For those a bit more on the fence, I suppose I'll elaborate a bit:In Shovel Knight, you play the titular knight in a battle against the Order of No Quarter. To do so, you travel to various stages and, in classic Megaman style, travel right while fighting enemies, platforming, and finding secrets. Throughout the level, you gather up Gems and Coins either outright, via slain enemies, or via secrets and chests, in order to gain Gold, which you can spend at the Village on various Health and Armor upgrades or items.Your shovel is your main weapon, with the ability to outright smack your enemies or pogo on them ala Duck Tales, and similarly can be used against blocks of various types of dirt and/or rock to traverse the screens. Items work similarly to Castlevania, with a limited resource that drains every time you use it (in Shovel Knight, it's pots, as opposed to Castlevania's hearts), though in Shovel Knight you gain the item permanently and can swap between them at your leisure. Even within the first 3 main stages, the selection of items you get is large enough to accomodate a variety of playstyles and strategies.The bosses and stages themselves are very remniscient of Megaman, with each stage having a particular theme carried out that matches the Boss. The Bosses themselves have a nice variety of attacks and pattern that, although at first are hard, can be read and manipulated, just like Megaman. Enemy types vary from neat and strange, like the helicopter-rat thing, to fairly standard fare, like the 2spooky skeleton. The music is always wonderfully fitting, and creating a sense of mood and enhancing all of the stages without being distracting.Movement feels good. Controls are responsive. Hitboxes don't feel wonky. In essence, this game is great.If you agreed with the first sentence, you probably already have the game.If you hate retro and/or have terrible taste, you probably weren't gonna get this game anyway.If you're interested, but worried $15 is a little steep, let me assure you that based off of the 3 main stages I've played so far and the size of the overworld map, that you are in for a decent amount of gameplay. Moreso if you want to replay anything, which you most likely will. It's absolutely worth it.Get digging.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Out of all the retro style games to come out over the last several years, Shovel Knight is perhaps the best one to emerge on the scene. The first successful game backed by Kickstarter and developed by Yacht Club Games, Shovel Knight is an instant classic that will only become greater as time goes on. One of the best things about Shovel Knight is despite being an ode to a long gone era of gaming it still easily manages to establish its own identity. There’s a good few retro style games that fail to do this and often suffer for it.The gameplay is simply top notch. The controls are simplistic and the input response is absolutely great as well. Furthermore, since the additional campaign of Plague of Shadows has been released while two more campaigns are on the way and in development as of writing this updated review the playable characters all play differently compared to each other. This is a good thing so you’re not just getting a reskinned playable character who behaves exactly the same. While I can’t say much for the upcoming campaigns due to lack of information, Plague of Shadows stands out noticeably in comparison to the regular story mode where you go through the game as Shovel Knight.The music is fantastic, hands down and no argument to be made. Jake Kaufman is a fantastic composer, but he wasn’t alone on the soundtrack. Manami Matsumae, a Japanese video gamer composer who started off at Capcom before becoming a freelance composer later on. She contributes several tracks to the whole score while Kaufman delivers the majority of the score. Each stage and each boss is given an incredibly fitting and catchy theme to them. Furthermore, Plague of Shadows was given a small score of its own for its own specific events and fights.For those seeking some challenge to their games then don’t be dissuaded by Shovel Knight, the game has something for everyone. For the main game itself, you can challenge yourself to see how fast you can go through it, see how you can handle completing the game without acquiring or using the relics, and doing both at the same time. There also exists a password system in the form of the name entering for each file where some names will change how the game functions, one code in particular making Shovel Knight twice his size. It’s something like that that showed the developers really thought of everything.In conclusion, you’re going to get an absolutely great game for a minimal cost. What also helps is that as mentioned before, Yacht Club Games are working on more free content for the game so you’ll be getting more for nothing as time goes on. Do not pass up on this game, it’s a missed golden opportunity that everyone should experience.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Shovel Knight is a 2d platformer that pays homage to and uses gameplay elements from classic NES games such as: Castlevania, Super Mario Bros. 3, Duck Tales and Mega Man series. Shovel Knight's partner, Shield Knight, disappears in the cursed tower and he goes on a journey to return to the tower to find her. Meanwhile the Evil Enchantress sends out her evil band of knights, The Order of No Quarter, to terrorize the land.I love this game. From the classic 8-bit graphics to the 8-bit music, it reminds me of the NES games I played when I was a youngin'. It takes some of the best elements from those games I mentioned above and brilliantly makes them its own thing. Shovel knight can pogo bounce on enemies with his shovel and smack them with it too. Later on there are armor and shovel powerups you can purchase but they're not necessary to complete the game. Along the way you can also find relics hidden in each stage that will help you considerably but remember to have enough magic points to use them. Health and magic upgrades can be purchased in town as well as relics you've missed as long as you completed the relic's corresponding stage. There's a warmup stage right in the beginning so you can get comfortable with how everything works before you set out to beat the Order of No Quarter. And you'll need all the practice you can get because the later stages can be quite difficult. Easy to pickup, hard to master, this is a great game if you have a nostalgic itch that needs scratching. Hell even if you don't have any nostalgia for the style, it's still a solid game. The developer, Yacht Club Games, still has plans to add more playable characters in the future but at the time of this review we have Shovel Knight and then Plague Knight to play as once you beat the game. I highly recommend this game. A must buy if you're a fan of classic NES platformer games or just platformers in general.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												What can be said about Shovel Knight that hasn't already been said by countless fans and reviewers? Shovel Knight is a retro action-platformer with RPG elements and an excellent soundtrack - as well as a great sense of humor. The game features classic elements, borrowing from games like Legend of Zelda: The Adventure of Link. Mega Man, Super Mario Brothers, and Castlevania. The game is difficult. But in all the proper ways that make retro games good. Never did I feel the game was unfair or trying to hard to be difficult for the sake of being difficult. Where most "Retro Style" games these days aim for a ridiculous level of frustration and difficulty, Shovel Knight focuses on making a good, challenging, and entertaining game that's fun to play. Plenty of replay value thanks to achievements being present that actually have some challenge to them (Don't get hit for a whole level, don't die for the entire game. Beat the game without buying any special weapons or items...etc.) So there's many ways to play, as well as the ability to choose what direction you want to go in on the world map. (Bosses and levels come in sets but the order you take them in is entirely up to you.) The game is designed well and the visuals and sound are fantastic. I recommend turning up the excellent soundtrack and enjoying what is destined to be considered a modern classic. 10 out of 10. No regrets.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Shovel Knight is an amazing game. Reminiscent of old NES/SNES games, it keeps the retro feel while still keeping to standards of some modern day games. When it comes to the actual meat of the game, I can't really say much negative about it: The gameplay is smooth and quite responsive, the story is beautiful and still simple to keep grasp of, and the visuals are top-notch for a game emulating older-style graphics. A negative that I can admit, however, is that it feels extremely short. In just a few hours, you can crank through all of the bosses and the side content of the main story and it leaves you wanting a little more. However, with the most recent update to it, it now has an added campaign where you play as one of the bosses through his own story, as well as adding a challenge mode for players feeling cocky or wanting a good test of their skill.All in all, even with the game feeling a fair bit short, Shovel Knight is a great game and is definitely worth the money for it. More updates are planned for it, including more of the side campaigns and other possible goodies, so pick it up!For Shovelry!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Double, trouble, soil and shovel,True knights wield not rake nor scuffle!    ....(a scuffle is a kind of hoe ;))Short Version:  AMAZING!Verbose Version:Shovel Knight is, hands-down, the most amazing new platformer game I've played in years.  Try it - I'm absolutely certain you'll feel the same!  If you're like me and grew up in the NES era, then your entire 3+ decade experience with video games is informed by those early titles.  Personally, I love the new and the old, playing the latest AAA productions in one moment, and retro system classics the next.  If you can identify with that, then you simply must put aside your Steam gaming backlog for a moment, and give yourself an evening to play Shovel Knight.  It has been awhile since a new title has compelled me to play straight through from beginning to end, but I was instantly gripped and can't wait to play *again* in NG+.Shovel Knight is clearly made by a team who knows this genre inside and out, and have produced a masterpiece that combines a unique cast of characters/abilities/equipment, perfect responsive controls (d-pad FTW, and if you play on a TV, best to mitigate any input lag!), beautiful visuals, top-notch music, superb writing, retro references galore, and every other possible indication that the creation of this title was a labour of love.  Honestly - I can't fault anything about it.  Shovel Knight is completely endearing to me, and my heart-felt congratulations go out to the team at Yacht Club Games - anybody who was a part of creating this has true reason to feel proud.  I will be watching this studio closely in the future.If you were ever a fan of any of the Mega Man, Castlevania, Super Mario Brothers, Ninja Gaiden, Contra, or Duck Tales games, then Shovel Knight is for you.  Or if you missed that generation and haven't caught up through virtual console, but enjoyed Dark Souls or any of the new Rayman games, again, it's a must play.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Let's talk about Shovel Knight. Shovel Knight is a nostalgia game. Shovel Knight is a NOSTALGIA game. They make a few things not very obvious at first and force you to fumble through the game to learn them. Breaking checkpoints for money is one. Being able to change the relic button to something actually useful is another.  The music, while catchy, gets very annoying after a while as well. It has a very short loop life and makes me long for something with more meat. MegaMan 2, Mario, Ducktales, they were all able to do better things with the music.  It also expects you to know Mario standards of being able to jump over the wall of the world, but it only lets you do this when it wants you to do this. So thinking this was a regular thing, I attempted to jump over the wall of the world and died because I didn't realize the developers didn't want me to be able to do that trick there when it worked elsewhere.  Getting away from those complaints, Shovel Knight is a fairly simple game with a platforming appeal that is tough, but forgiving, and in general, a fun game. The mechanics are fairly simple, there's a fun bit of exploration involved, trying to figure out every nook and cranny you need to break.7/10

After giving it a playthrough I must say: Shovel Knight is a really great game.The gameplay, art, characters, soundtrack, pacing... everything is superb and spot on. I enjoyed it from start to finish. Sure some moments (the latter levels in particular) had quite a lot more challenge to them, but it's certainly far from impossible. All of this on top of 8-bit graphics and 8-bit music, neither letting down for the smallest moment throughout the game. Bravo!Definitely recommending this one.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												The best NES game never made. Extremely tight controls. Game plays like a cross between Mega Man/Ducktales/Darkwing Duck with a SMB3/Kirby-esque overworld map, and towns reminiscent of Faxanadu (first and foremost) and to a lesser extent Castlevania 2, Zelda 2, etc.The game does pay a lot of attention to modern conventions though as well. It is somewhat easier, vastly less frustrating, and much longer than your typical old-school NES games. Saving is done after each level. Each level has 5 or so checkpoints. When you die, you don't lose set lives, but gold, which you can get back.One of my favorite games of 2014, by a wide margin. If you played NES games or just like 2d platformers or retro-games an absolute must-buy. This game is amazing.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												The platforming is solid and the combat goes from just "okay" to "feels great" through quality upgrades across the game. (I recommend getting the double jump slash shovel upgrade first when you gain access to it.) That and an assortment of other upgrades really give you good reason to keep investing into your character.The levels are well done with ample secrets throughout and only a small handful of spots that were lacking in the design department. You can tell the inconsistencies when looking at deaths per level as they spike across the levels instead of increasing steadily or remaining similar throughout (depending on what their intent for difficulty was).The art is an homage to classic NES design with a nice palette and excellent animations for almost all characters in the game. The music is spot on and gets you into the feel of the game, though nothing stuck out to me as being "zomg amazeballs"; that is, I don't find myself humming any of the songs, but that doesn't mean they're not good.Definitely check it out, there's a lot to discover and the game has some quality platforming that harkens back to yesteryear.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Shovel Knight gets a lot of praise, which is not for no reason. Many would call it 'nostalgic', but I personally think it's great in it's own way; aside from the classic graphics and recognisable soundtracks many will recognise from the bit-era.In short:GOOD+ Nice ol' iconic platforming, defeating your enemies, aquiring ways to defeat said enemies... a great formula done almost perfectly and with a bunch of new engaging ideas!+ Level design and atmosphere. It's a small game, but filled to the brim with personality. You'll see a lot of old themes like the 'halloween/undead' stage and the always hated ice-stage, but also a lot of fresh mechanics and themes for such a simple platformer.+ Bosses deserve their own mention. I always love games with good bosses. I know many feel the same, so here ya go. Definite plus.+ Though simple, the story is actually pretty intruiging. You might see all the twists coming, but they still do their own original thing with it. Which is why I like the Shovel Knight and Shield Knight characters quite a lot. It's extremely solid, and open for many new stories to build onto it. + Soundtrack also deserves it's own mention. Though all the iconic sound effects are the way we know them, the music really is the gigantic lovely cherry on top. + There are multiple ways to play the game to give yourself more challenge, and the game also comes with a few achievements to hint at some of these other plastyles!NOT SO GOOD- I played it on a keyboard but I admit it would probably be FAR nicer with a controller. So if you don't have one the controls might be a bit annoying.- Relatively short. It has pretty good replayability, but somehow you still feel like they could've done so much more. Especially when you look at the Mario3-esque overworld map going on.- Instant-death spikes? Yes. But it's about the worst kind; the sideways ones. Slip one pixel to much to the left at a snail pace? Dead. It's reaaally something platformers should abolish for some more creative ideas. Dying to a boss at a difficult fight is challenging and fun. Doing an entire section of platforming without a scratch and dying right before a checkpoint? Frustrating.- Though I earlier praised the music. It tends to change to another version EVERYtime you enter another section of a town or something. Normally, this is great, gives every section it's own feel. But here it's actually taking away the atmosphere it's supposed to give because it keeps switching every 4 seconds when you're running through the towns. And that's basically it aside from some personal thoughts. I could be getting a little bit ahead of myself by saying Shovel Knight, the character, would be perfect lined up to the likes of Mario and Sonic. If only in extremely iconic design and the world his character lives in. Extremely simple, but very recognisable and engaging.  For example, I wouldn't be surprised to see him or Shield Knight in Smash Bros, things like that. I'd personally love to see far more of this, so I hope the team is planning on expanding this fun world of knighthood and I recommend this to any one who's up for a good old school challenge!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												This game was my favorite out of 2014. I did miss a lot of games in 2014 but that still can't deny how great this is. I am a huge NES classic fan especially Mega Man and this game is a must for any fan of the NES classics. It is an amazing throwback with great visuals and an AMAZING soundtrack. Think Castlevania meets Ducktales meets Mega Man.  It has a world map straight out of Mario 3 and 8 bosses with an intro stage along with a village where you can buy and sell things, and an airship with armor and shovel upgrades. The bosses are creative, colorful in personality, and fun to fight. All the boss patterns are fun and interesting and with no order of each move it can be challenging. There are many secret areas in where you can get more loot, relics, or music sheets to certain songs that you can sell and then play in the village. The gameplay and design are fairly thought out. You stop in your place to slash with your shovel. You can use your shovel to use a pogostick-like attack. Later in the game you can get a charge slash that makes the movement really awkward when you charge it. The movement feels a little too slow in my opinion and the jumps feel too high in comparison. I rarely felt like I was cheated out of a life but it did happen and I can't excuse that. The challenge is lacking for the style of game. You are never faced with too much at one time with no chance to get the pattern. It always feels a bit too safe. I never died to losing all my life or to a boss. I only died to bottomless pits and spikes that sometimes felt cheap. This game is built around a speedrun and to get full completion you will need to master that speedrun and that is only a sign of good design. I could go on and on about everything this game has to offer but i'd rather have anyone reading this be playing this great platformer. So what are you doing still reading this?! Go play Shovel Knight! You won't regret it. 9/10 Would shovel again

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Do you like to play games released in 1983 - 1991? Are you a sucker for anything 8-bit? Do you lust for the NES and its many timeless classics? Do you like platformers that are challenging but not too challenging that you'll end up throwing your controller across the room? If you answered yes to any of these questions, then I recommend this game to you!A great, charming, challenging platformer that throws you back to the days of the NES with music and levels inspired by the likes of games including, but not limited to Mega Man, Zelda 2, Castlevania, Super Mario Bros. 3, Ducktales and more. Plus, it's getting free updates, such as campaigns where you can play as some of the bosses with their own unique abilities, and a gender swap mode.While other indie games have tried their hand at making a retro looking and feeling game, most of the time, they fell flat and the retro aesthetics felt shoehorned/forced in. This isn't the case at all in Shovel Knight, it looks, feels, sounds and plays exactly like a game released for the NES would (although the devs did have to push beyond a few of the NES's limits in some cases.) Only real complaint is no exclusive content for the PC version (PS3/4/Vita get the Kratos boss fight, Xbox One gets the BattleToads level, 3DS gets the StreetPass arena + Shovel Knight amiibo functionality, and the Wii U will be getting co-op and other functionality linked to the Shovel Knight amiibo.) That may change in the future, and if it does, I will update this review to reflect that.All in all, this review does not do the game justice. It's one of the best platformers I've played in years. No, scratch that, it's one of the best platformers I've ever played! Buy it now. NOW!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Shovel Knight is a very well made platformer game made in the spirit of NES.  I was able to complete this game in a few hours over roughly 3 days time.  I usually only write reviews if a game is either very exceptional, or very terrible.  Fortunately, this game is very exceptional.  Just to briefly summarize, the game is about Shovel Knight, a hero who is trying to rescue his best friend, Shield Knight from an evil sorceress.  The game has a ton of 2d platforming action, and some of the best game control mechanics I've played since Super Mario Bros 3.  You go from area to area, defeating all of these other knights, each one specializing in a particular area.  While all that is going on, you visit a small town in between quests, so you can drop off "shanties" for the local musician to archive for you.  Speaking of music, this game features some of the best chip music in ages, and there is a lot to hear.  So as you are getting through all of the quests, you are also upgrading your armor, your shovel, and gathering new magic spells to use to get you through the areas.  They designed the levels where you have to use certain powers to proceed, introducing new challenges as the game progresses.  I don't want to spoil the ending for you, but I would definitely recommend this game for anyone who loved the NES/SNES, and enjoys a good challenging classic style 2D platformer game.  I can see myself playing this game for years to come!  Nice work, Yacht Club Games!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												So, it's been a while since my last review. I've been busy. And when I got time I just didn't feel like it. But now I have (finally) finished Shovel Knight and said to myself: "Hey, why not?"Shovel Knight. A game that came at least a year or two ago and I have just managed to finish. In 14 hours. Don't get fooled, though, those are 14 hours through out nearly a year, for reasons I'll go over later on.This is a game that aims to bring out nostalgia from the old great times of NESS games (I actually wasn't around by then, but, hey, it works too). You play as Shovel Knight, a knight... with a spade instead of a sword. You are on a quest to find the Evil Enchantress and rescue your old friend Shield Knight from her and her Order of No Quarter, a selection of the most bombastic knights I've seen in a videogame. The game will keep throwing in new mechanics, enemies and challanges until the very end of the game, so you don't get bored; and without the hardware limitations of the NESS era, the guys over at the Yatch development studio have managed to create a game with enough content to be considered a game worthy of today's standards without dropping the old times feeling.Which gets me to... Shovel Knight tries to mimic a lot of things that games before the second millenia had, and the difficulty is something that is replicated masterfully. And I almost wish they hadn't. Oh dear god, at the end of my fourteen-hour-long run I had a death count of 168. That's more than 10 deaths per hour, at about an average of a shameful fall into a bottomless pit or getting my skull obliterated by a boss every six minutes. I remember that, sometimes, I said to myself "I still have an hour or so of free time and I'm bored. Let's see what I can play..." while I scrolled through my Steam Library, only to find Shovel Knight, and thinking "Yeah... maybe another day. I don't feel like flinging my laptop across the room right now". This game takes guts to play. And it turns out that what I finished was just the base game, and that I still have New Game Plus and the Plague Knight free expansion left. Oh, boy...What can I say? This is a game that is going head first into my "games that I love and hate" list.+ Entertaining gameplay with very simple mechanics.+ Very easy to learn. Almost impossible to master.+ Has the right length for a game like this. And, quite honestly, I don't know if I would have been able to stand much more of it.+ An absolute ton of secrets, side quests and achievements. Completionists better know what are they getting into...- This is no walk in the park whatsoever. The game WILL frustrate you, and the risk-vs-reward sistem is totally stacked against you. Just so you know.- Some parts are just downright ridiculous. Either perform a pixel-perfect sequence of jumps and mid-air item usages or fall to your death and lose a quarter of your current money and about a sixth of your leftover sanity. You missed the plataform and killed yourself before you could get to the point you died so you could recover your loot? Welp, sucks to be you: there goes another quarter of your earnings and the other one is lost forever! Christ, I think I rage quited about three times in my first playthrough.This game gets a 7.5 out of 10. Definetely deserves to be called a "classic".

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I'm sure you already know if this is your kind of game or not, as an NES MegaMan clone. Stages are varied enough to be fun with interesting patterned boss fights at the end of each stage.However, this is one of those games that wants you to "pick your own" difficulty level, because there is no traditional difficulty selection. The mid-stage checkpoints are all optional, and most of the health/mp upgrades as well. Personally, playing through it with using all of those, the game was far too easy, tallying up the deaths at the end most were from one specific boss fight and the bonus areas. If you get all the health upgrades as they become available, it becomes extremely hard to die due to running out of HP, most of my deaths came from bottomless pits. On top of that, some of the sub-weapons seem to give you invincibility when you use them, making them go-to weapons for every single boss fight afterward, but thats also part of your own difficulty level if you want to use it.Having said that, the game feels great to play, the art is true to its NES style in pallet and always maintaining a 1:1 pixel ratio, with good slightly-better-than-NES music as well. I'd recommend to anyone that enjoys either MegaMan or platformers in general.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Shovel Knight is the first game developed by Yacht Club Games. Initially getting kicked off as a Kickstarter campaign, the game rapidly gained followers and backing, eventually getting released on Windows, 3DS, and Wii U, with ports to other consoles and operating systems appearing later. The game achieved much success, but is it well-deserved? Let's find out.Story:In a land where heroic knights roamed, there were two heroes whose names were known throughout the land: Shovel Knight, and Shield Knight. With their signature shovel and red shield in hand, the two were inseparable, until one quest led them to the ominous Tower of Fate. What they found there, would change their destines forever...Without mentioning spoilers, the plot of Shovel Knight maintains a persistent charm to it.  The characters, while not completely fleshed out, are (mostly) still interesting enough to carry it. The people are likable, the presentation is good, and the quest is good enough to make you want to see how it ends. That being said, Shovel Knight's story is not ground-breaking in any way: it is cliche'd but endearing, and integrates itself well with its gameplay.Gameplay:Shovel Knight shares its gameplay characteristics with many 2D side-scrolling platform games in the industry, but what sets it apart is how it is presented. The controls aren't handed to you on a silver platter:  instead, the stage design is worked around introducing you to them intuitively, as needed, without feeling forced. This is absolutely essential to maintaining a balance between challenging gameplay and enjoyment, and Shovel Knight does this almost flawlessly. The main goal of each stage is to get to the end of it, defeating enemies, collecting treasures, and fighting bosses. The stage designs and enemies remain unique throughout the game, with many hidden secrets in each stage, reminiscent of Megaman stages. Rather than a set number of lives, dying forces you to drop some money bags where you died and pushes you back to the last activated check point, giving you a chance to regain that money later, similar to souls in the Dark Souls series. Outside stages, there are towns where you can upgrade your health and magic, or buy relics, shovel abilities, and armor to help you fight.Unfortunately, the game is quite short, easily clearable under 10 hours. In addition, there is not much incentive to replay it on New Game+, except to get the 100% on a higher difficulty. Visuals:The graphics pay homage to old 8-bit graphics games of yore, and what a lovely homage it is. Shovel Knight's pixelated art is, simply put, dazzling. The animation is fantastic, the stages and enemies look great, and the attention to detail in the background is amazing. Even if you're not usually a fan of that peculiar style, it is easy to appreciate it, and is one of the game's strongest aspects.Sound:And here comes the other strong aspect of the game. There is no other way to say this: Shovel Knight's OST is brilliantly well done. Jake Kaufman (Contra 4, Red Faction: Guerrilla, DuckTales: Remastered, Shantae) worked together with ex-Capcom composer Manami Matsumae (Mega Man, Mega Man 10, and others) to create some sweet, sweet music. Catchy beats blend together to give each location a unique experience and truly bring the game to life. I highly recommend getting the OST if you can, as it is well worth it.Conclusion:With fun, challenging gameplay, dazzling art, and great music, Shovel Knight offers a short, yet  great experience. It is a must-have for any fans of the genre. If you see it on sale, immediately get it.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Shovel Knight is one of the best games I've ever played. It's on my top 5 favorite games of all time. The platforming is smooth and the graphics feel great. It's what other inde games should strive to be. The Shovel Knight campagin is great. The first level teaches you everything you'd probablly need to know without any tutorial. The levels fit the style of the game very well and the bosses are nice and simple but still give you enough of a challenge.The Plague Knight campagin is a great addon. The addon is free and it's mechanics are completly different but still extremely engaging. The boss battles are a new challenge even though they do about the same thing as they would in the Shovel Knight campagin. This is a very well designed game and I can't wait for the Specter Knight and King Knight campagins.Specter Knight's campagin was amazing. The new wall jump and dash slash mechanics took some getting used to but they really fit well. The boss battles have some new things so you may have to approach them differently than Shovel and Plague Knight. The story also expanded quite a bit. This campagin is a prequel to shovel knight and more lore is told. It was a very nice campaign and I can't wait to see what they'll do for King Knight.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												This game falls in the extremely rare category of one I did not enjoy but would still definitely recommend, presuming you're someone that enjoys precision platforming.  Despite this, I still finished the game, and went back for a few achievements in New Game Plus.  Shovel Knight is extremely well made, and lovingly crafted -- that much is clear.  In fact, I'd argue it's almost too well made -- it's like when a record label sets out to manufacture a song that uses the absolute most pleasing melody, with the perfect rhythm that only years of cold market research and focus testing could produce -- as opposed to some pure, deep, soulful and meaningful expression of life experience by some aspiring and talented singer-songwriter (e.g. Spice Girls vs. Johnny Cash).  That's not to say either method is "wrong"; they're just different.  This game is suspiciously good.The aesthetic... --I mean, if the modernizing features alone weren't a dead giveaway (e.g. widescreen resolution, extended color range, high quality audio), one might mistake it for an old NES game from the '80s; an absolutely masterful presentation in the retro style from the 8-bit Nintendo era.  I've heard some say that the game would've been right at home on the NES.  Of course, ignoring all of the technical impossibilities of such an assertion, some form of it could've.  However, the way I see it, it both absolutely could not, but already kinda did...You see, Shovel Knight is a great game in its own right; aside from the fan service and nostalgia for an era of gaming long past, it stands up.  A person of any age, regardless of gaming background, could find a lot to like in it, but it especially caters to those of us that grew up playing games of this style, and boy does it hit all the right notes -- like I said, a bit too well.  ...and for me, this is the part where the argument that Shovel Knight stands on its own breaks down, because the only originality I see in it is the token shovel-wielding player character.  Sure, it crafts a personality for itself with its whimsical aesthetic and interesting bosses, but it feels like it all came together as a product of imitation.Some of the best systems and mechanics from some of the best, most iconic games of the NES era were carefully selected and combined into Shovel Knight.  The overworld map system from Super Mario Bros. 3, the boss and item progression from Mega Man, and heavy elements of Castlevania playstyle are a few examples.  That's not to say this is a problem, nor would I accuse the developers of plagiarism; game development is a highly iterative process.  You could critically examine most games today and find roots well-established by games the preceded it; that's just progress.My point though is a counter-argument to the idea that Shovel Knight could've been at home on the NES.  It simply couldn't, because it is a perfection of all of those games that came before it; it just wouldn't exist without them.  It is a modernized adaptation of our best memories from a long-past era of gaming, formed to fit with the conveniences and features we've come to expect today.As for me?  I mentioned I didn't enjoy it.  I actually found the experience a lot more stressful than I expected it to be.  Not that I necessarily felt cheated, or that I took issue with the difficulty ramp (by the end, I found it extremely challenging, though fair).  My skill and reflexes felt informed by the level design, commensurate to my ability (I did beat the game after all).  There were moments of triumph, where I managed to successfully execute difficult maneuvers on the first try, but there were contrasting moments of trial and error, akin to the Dark Souls experience where you learn enough from each mistake to do better on subsequent attempts.  I got the impression that it was never going to exceed my skill level -- despite how crazy it became at times --that I could find some way to force my way through it, and even when I was sure the game might beat me, sure enough, I found a way through.The problem for me is that Shovel Knight managed to trigger my anxiety in a way that few games have ever been able.  For me, the execution and platforming would often feel harrowing, is if I was risking and wagering far more than was actually on the line.  I don't know where this feeling came from, because ultimately the death penalty isn't all that impactful, and there are enough checkpoints throughout each level to keep the repetition tolerable.  ...but I felt stressed out and tense the whole time, and it just wasn't a good feeling.  I expect, for most people -- especially for any fans of this genre -- this will not be a problem, but I just couldn't relax, and that made it that much more difficult to just have fun.My personal edge-case aside, it's a wonderfully made game, and stands as one of the best examples of percision platforming I've seen.  It's well loved and respected for a reason, and I would still easily recommend giving it a shot.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												9.5/10Shovel Knight is a modern classic, literally. It looks and feels like a classic 2d jump`n`run and also plays like one to a degree, but at the same time feels modern, fresh.The controls are great (controller as well as KB+M). The character design is very creative, funny and unique. They are like characters from Megaman or animes/cartoons from the 80s and 90s.Every level has its own theme with unique enemy types and gimmicks, so there is always some change.There is also character progression. You find new Relics (skills), buy new Equipment and upgrade your stats, everything of this works really good. What I really liked were the last 2 stages and especially the last bossfight which had a nice ideas and was also a great moment story-wise.I dont want to repeat all those standard sentences though. Its simple, if you like any kind of platformer and you like challenging games, this is a no-brainer.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Shovel Knight. Why aren't you playing this yet? BUY IT THE ZOMGBBQHYPEHYPEHYPE!Fangirling aside, let's talk about the technical side of things.Graphics:It's pixel art. Not strictly 8-bit pixel art actually. In an actual 8-bit machine they can only render 8 colours at a time in any particular sprite or layer. Which explains why in true NES games, the colour of the enemies change together with your character. (Biggest culprit again Megaman series)Shovel Knight has a lot of places where it looks 8-bit at first glance. But, if you colour pick and line the shades out they do break the limit.How did they keep that 8-bit feel? Colour choice. It all boils down to the painting.Gameplay:Perfectly right controls. It will jump the moment you press jump. Some games have a slight delay in jumping but this doesn't have it. If you inch, he will inch. If you pogo stick he will pogo stick. Oh, yes he can bounce on enemies and some objects like Scrooge McDuck.Best played on a controller for very good reasons. There will be really tricky platform sections where a bad keyboard cause a lot of needless suffering. Which leads to the next section.Difficulty:If you're the kind of person who have very bad jump timing/slipping off platforms, this will be a very very hard game for you.If you're a fresh newbie in the platforming scene, expect a steep difficulty curve.If you're more experienced in casual platforming, still expect a somewhat steep curve.If you're an old veteran of the NES Nintendo Hard era, this is definitely the game for you!There will be times where you will die. Repeatedly. And you will feel like flipping the table because That One Section gets in the way. Boss fights are very fast paced and expect a few tries before getting the hang of it. Unless you're in the NES veteran level.Things do get easier as you get more relics (Magic) and upgrade the Shovel Knight's gear (Armour/Shovel). But they're not going to prevent accidental falls from derpiness :PThe map is mapped out ala Mario Style, which means mini-areas and mini-bosses will move around the map after completing each stage. I won't spoil who they actually are.Stages can be replayed to get more money (or you missed a secret) but bewarned! In Mega Man the bosses dissapear for good after you beat them.Nope. Not in Shovel Knight. Bosses WILL wait for you at the end of the stage. New relics will make some stages a ton easier to farm.... just come prepared.All in all, expect a challenge!Music:All the music here are Chiptunes. It might take a while to get used to the kind of beepy gritty sharpy feel. The most earworm tune is the village music. Despite the high quality of the visual production, the music takes a while to catch on.When you do get used to it, it's really nice! Adds a lot to the feel of the stage and the game in general.Conclusion:What are you doing? BUY IT NOW! The only folks I'd think twice for are those with terrible coordination. But don't fret! You can try! I used to suck really hard in platforming. Then eventually with practice I get better. Platforming is like riding a bike, you'll remember it for life.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Well, it's no Mega Man. and it's no Duck Tales. neither is it Castlevania nor Zelda II nor Bionic Commando nor Ninja Gaiden, etc. etc. you get the idea. I guess it's the ultimate retro-nostalgia-pandering game, built entirely out of old references like a Tarantino film. except instead of excessive swearing it has excessive bad puns.Most retro style indie games will at least try to innovate a little, or throw in a gimmick, but I couldn't find a single new idea in this entire game. If this were made in the 80s, it wouldn't be remembered as a classic, it would be that decent-yet-forgettable title that ripped off everything creative around it. Kinda like most big studio games we get today, heh.But in the end, it's still good! It is an adequate platformer, very polished production. A little too easy, not very clever level design, but there's not a single BAD thing anywhere in it. It took no risks, but it has no ugly stains.+ The soundtrack by Jake Kaufman is awesome stuff. The main sidequest has you collecting the bgm sheet music, as well you should.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I loved it, and i love it. I really do. It's essentially 95 percent Megaman and maybe 5 percent some other games but it's really good no matter what. Controls feel great, there's tons of little secrets, I adore the music and the bosses are probably the best part. The game is fairly easy (nowhere near as hard as Meatboy and others) with maybe a smidgen of difficulty at the last level. It depends probably what items you use. If you want to cheese it or are too frusterated you can pretty much just phase locket most of the game. The bosses are the best part. Almost none of them are wait-around-and-hit-weakpoints. You can attack and stay on their butts the whole time. I really like that you can play super aggressively on them and take quite a few hits before going down. Level design is pretty much exactly Megaman style but obviously melee. My only problem is the game is absurdly short. I beat it in 5 hours and thats after doing all the levels too. There's a new game plus mode but it doesn't change much at all. Less checkpoints, no food, and enemies do more damage. No level change or anything so that kind of bummed me out. There's also a code to replace most of the text with "butt" so yeah. This is probably my favorite platformer.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Fantastic game. Here's some feedback about weaker points in the game.There is "faux low framerate" in this game which threw me off a bit. For example when opening the menu it's very framey, same for the cursors in the menu. Didn't really like that aspect of it. I had to double check that my game was actually running at 60 fpsThe armor and weapon upgrades were very tame. Being able to electrocute the ground on the condition when being on full health sounds great, in reality you fart out a tiny spark that hovers over the ground. Of all the armors, I just used the silver one which gave me an extra attack. All the other ones were boring. When you progress further in the game the checkpoints get further and further apart. It did get annoying towards the end and I didn't really feel like exploring anymore, too much risk.I would've like more optional bosses towards the end game. I liked the wandering travellers but felt like there were one or two missing just before the end boss.I felt like the game was already pretty challenging from the start. Maybe some more gradual increase in difficulty would've been nice.I didn't really like the "dark sections that are lit up by lightning" sections because the dark to light ratio was way too high. For every split second of light you have multiple seconds of darkness where you can't really move.Positive points: the powerups are fantastic, they really change up the game, the npcs are interesting and fun, music is great, combat is fun and tight, ending is great.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												At first glance, this game just appears to be another indie platformer that is retro themed.At second glance, you look at it as "Maybe this one will be different."At third glance, you're having the time of your life just pummeling away at enemies with a shovel.This game controls very tightly with simplistic (yet complex to carry out in some circumstances) controls. One thing that I always bore in mind, was how awesome the difficulty curve was. From the very first level, you are getting tossed at monsters that are difficult to beat (but not impossible) and techniques that you'll be using for the rest of the game. The healthy difficulty curve really contribute to this game's replayability, too. I can see myself in the future doing another run of this game for some good old fashioned fun.On a personal note, this is one of the few games that can make you feel emotions. Any time during the Shield Knight dream sequences, the music and overall theme did an excellent job at making you specifically go for Shield Knight. I missed her once on the third dream sequence and almost cried. Not to mention at the end of the game I felt tears welling up in my eyes when she was going to sacrifice herself to save you, then audibly cheered when it turned out she was alive.I haven't gotten that excited about a video game since I was eight years old when I first beat Ocarina of Time. No game has been able to capture that old fashioned sense of achievement since then for me. To me, that rates this game as one of my all-time favorites.I know my review will become blotted out by "Bounced a shovel off of a bubble 10/10" But, this game is a solid 10/10 in my book. Excellent music, tight controls, good (but not obtrusive) storyline, and awesome gameplay. It's a must-play.

content:

												Shovel Knight is an homage to the golden age of gaming.  The style of overworld map is taken straight from Super Mario 3.  The gameplay feels like the best of both Castlevania and Mega Man.  It even has an element of Dark Souls, where dying causes Shovel Knight to drop gold that can recovered by returning to the spot where you died.  There are plenty of power-ups, upgrades, and secrets to acquire.  If retro platforming is your thing, you'll get everything you want from Shovel Knight.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												There are way too many "retro-style" games that aren't anything like old games, which only seem to be "retro" style because their creators are pretentious and/or lazy.Shovel Knight is not one of those games.It looks perfect. It sounds perfect. It, shockingly enough in this world of "hey retro means really hard right?" games, PLAYS perfect. It gets tough at points, tough enough for you to die at the same point five times, tough enough for you to scream out loud, and yet manages to get it right to the point where you DON'T say the game is unfair, because it's not. If you die, you certainly know why, and know what to do next to not die (and then you invariably screw up and die again).Playing this game makes you feel like a child again. It's a familiar and nostalgic, yet completely new and refreshing experience.If you grew up playing video games, you HAVE to play this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												I haven't played such a great game in ages!Shovel Knight brings back the fun and challenge of the old side-scrolling platforms from the 80s and 90s, but it remixes everything to create something new and fresh.This game is flawless.The story is simple, but does it's job, the challenge is perfect, the controls are absolutely tight and responsive, the graphics awesome and the soundtrack incredible!The best thing is that every single level is different from the previous one.Both graphics and type of challenges/enemies/puzzle change every time, so it's impossible to get bored!The game is hard, (not insanely, though), but never unfair.If you die it's only your fault, and every level can be completed with a bit of practice.The graphics are awesome! True 8 bit style (which is quite hard to replicate in such an elegant way), but with a much richer colour palette than every NES game put togheter, and the animations are amazing.The soundtrack is a tremendous achievement!I haven't been listening to such a great soundtrack in ages! Lovely tunes to pump up the action and i sometimes listen to it while doing other stuff..I'll conclude with a special mention to the boss battles; many and quite elaborated.If you like 2D (old school) Platform/SidesScrolling games, you'll love this one!Pros:- Nice Channalge (Hard, but not impossible)- Tight and precise controls- Amazing 8-bit graphics- Unbelievable Soundtrack- Amazing variety (in a matter of levels and type of challenges)- An Achievment Hunter's heaven (There are many fun challenges)Cons:- NOTHING (and i haven't been writing something like this in a long while)This game was really a surprise!

												Whoosh. Finally completed the game. Only 10 stages, but still took me 10 hours to complete it. (Still didn't beat NG+ however).PROS: - Amazing, SNES-like graphics;- Great level design;- Tight controls;- Trading cards and achievements;- Fun boss fights;- Awesome soundtrack.CONS:- Very, very, very, VERY hard;- Propeller Knight's stage feeled rushed;- Completionists will hate this game - you need to win the game without dying (which is nearly impossible, considering the difficulty) to get an achievement.Overall, this was a very good game. There's also upcoming FREE DLC that will allow you to play as the evil knights, with new stages and story. I give this game a: 9/10. Hopefully, when the DLC comes out, I can give this game a 10/10.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Shovel Knight scratches an itch I didn't even know that I had. Its retro graphics combined with chiptune music remind me of the old Mega Man games, which is a franchise I loved as a child. The gameplay is quick, and crisp. You don't find yourself blundering because of the controls. The bosses themselves aren't too difficult; it's the levels that are your biggest challenge. The platforming in this game requires some practice. Luckily, the game doesn't run on an extra life system. When you die, you lose gold which you can recover as you restart.The soundtrack for the game accents it so perfectly that the game seems less bright if you turn the music down. I don't say that a lot about soundtracks, but this one is definitely worth putting on headphones for. The story is actually pretty surprising. I thought it would be a cookie cutter hero vs. villains story, but it turns out to be so much more.Definitely worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												A lot of people seem to think of this game as the Messiah of all games - The peak of what we're capable of achieving. This has led to this game acquiring a somewhat over-the-top amount of praise.Is the game good? Yes! Is it great? Yeah.. Is it the best thing ever? Not quite.Let's be reasonable here: It's a fun retro-platformer offering a lot of challenge and bringing back a lot of mechanics from older titles that we haven't seen used in a larger and more popular mainstream title for a long time. Please, do keep in mind that some of these mechanics were left behind for a reason though.It's a good, fun game - Possibly even close to a masterpiece, but it is *not* 'the one game to rule them all'.What does it do really well?- Tight controls and Dualshock 4 compatibility without any outside tools needed.- Even thought it's an old style, the visuals are nice if you enjoy pixel-art.- A good sense of humor and a decent, if slightly confusing, story.- It's got a great deal of content and, like most games in this genre, it's more or less infinitely replayable. What does it do not-so-well?- An absolutely minute amount of bugs that can ruin your day. These are extremely rare in my experience, but while the game is solid it's not bulletproof.- Some of the mechanics are.. Well, not so fun. Rooms going completely dark, forcing you to go around not really sure of where you're going or what's up above or beneath you. Bosses that have a slightly tiresome amount of RNG and lack of control to them leading to some not always very fair deaths. Mechanics that take control away from the player and leaves you relying on luck more than skill, and some screens where a you run the possible risk of getting a setup of hazards that's unpassable. (It's rare, but it happens, and it basically means a reset/death.)I'd recommend this game to any platform enthusiast, but at the same time.. If you're like me and don't like mechanics where you can't rely on skill, this game *will* frustrate you every now and again. The difficulty curve towards the end also takes a rather sudden, massive leap, making the second half of the game far, far harder than the first half without really easing you into it.Great game, definitely a classic, and something I'm going to play more of - It's not the best game I've ever seen, nor evne the best of this particular genre. Top 5, but not number 1.

content:
Posted: February 19
												This game is incredible. Shovel Knight is a game about a knight, clad in cerulean armor, with a shovel for a weapon. He used to roam the lands with his love, until they were seperated at the Tower of Fate. Now, Shovel Knight must rise up once more to protect the valley from the Order of No Quarter.This game is super freaking hard. Maybe it's just because I suck, but this game is difficult. You will ragequit. You will swear at it. But at the end of the game, you will love it. It's a combination of tons of different NES games. It has the pogo-jump from Ducktales, the knockback effect from Castlevania, and the boss battles and instakill spikes from MegaMan. If you loved those games, you will love this. I died a total of about 100 times. No joke, no sarcasm. 100 times. I think maybe a little more. That's how hard this game is. If you're not a fan of constantly dying, you will not like this game. If you don't like gorgeous 8-bit graphics and incredible chiptune songs, you will also not like this song. But if you put aside the "terrible" graphics and the "♥♥♥♥♥♥" music, you will discover an incredible experience.Plus, there's a new free expansion for the game, and another coming up, that lets you play as Plague Knight and Spectre Knight, so there's a pretty good replayablity to it.9.5/10I don't like dying.TL:DR: It's difficult, but good. Buy it.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												if you enjoyed any of the following, you will likely enjoy this game:-mega man series-ducktales (nes)-super mario bros. 3-zelda II: the adventure of link.a veritable love letter to all four and then some, the game features solid gameplay that teaches you through gameplay and not tutorials, a downright boss ost accented by the original mega man 1 composer (!!!), and a goofy, cheesy story that'll at least make you roll your eyes and grin, if nothing else. while i reference the four above as reference material, the game actually plays fairly uniquely and has its own strengths (and weaknesses) by comparison--it's a rare gem among others of its kind that shines in its ability to utilize its tools for its own sake rather than relying on parody and mockery to do its job for it--it's a game that's genuinely fun, rather than only being fun because it makes you think about the fun you had playing the games it takes its cues from.the game took me about 8-9 hours to complete--rather impressive for an nes-style indie game--and there's a new game+ mode that will probably take a little longer due to increased difficulty. there are also codes you can use to make the game easier/harder/sillier, if you're into that. my main complaints are mainly in difficulty spikes--some areas/bosses are far harder than others, and it can feel a lot like the difficulty takes a sudden dip or jump depending on where you are. i personally had lots of trouble in some of the later stages only to beat the bosses barely getting touched, if at all. the price point may also be an issue for some--$15 isn't terribly cheap, and though i feel the game is worth it for its polish, you might do well waiting for it to inevitably go on sale if you're not sure you'd enjoy it. all in all, this is a game that has the look of a classic and the feel of a well-constructed platformer--if you enjoy platformers at all, you're missing out if you skip over this game.also, there's a mode where every important word is replaced with the word butt. 11/10 would steel my shovel again.

												I'm leery of retro-styled games, but Shovel Knight does right what every game with "8-Bit" or "Pixel" in the title does wrong: it recognizes that what made the old NES classics...classics...is a strong focus on content and production, from story to character design to sound to gameplay. Shovel Knight is not AN NES game, but the NES game you would save your allowance for, the one that would cause your friends to show up to your house a little more often. And that's what games in this vein should aspire to be.
