Posted: September 25, 2014
												At first glance, this game just appears to be another indie platformer that is retro themed.At second glance, you look at it as "Maybe this one will be different."At third glance, you're having the time of your life just pummeling away at enemies with a shovel.This game controls very tightly with simplistic (yet complex to carry out in some circumstances) controls. One thing that I always bore in mind, was how awesome the difficulty curve was. From the very first level, you are getting tossed at monsters that are difficult to beat (but not impossible) and techniques that you'll be using for the rest of the game. The healthy difficulty curve really contribute to this game's replayability, too. I can see myself in the future doing another run of this game for some good old fashioned fun.On a personal note, this is one of the few games that can make you feel emotions. Any time during the Shield Knight dream sequences, the music and overall theme did an excellent job at making you specifically go for Shield Knight. I missed her once on the third dream sequence and almost cried. Not to mention at the end of the game I felt tears welling up in my eyes when she was going to sacrifice herself to save you, then audibly cheered when it turned out she was alive.I haven't gotten that excited about a video game since I was eight years old when I first beat Ocarina of Time. No game has been able to capture that old fashioned sense of achievement since then for me. To me, that rates this game as one of my all-time favorites.I know my review will become blotted out by "Bounced a shovel off of a bubble 10/10" But, this game is a solid 10/10 in my book. Excellent music, tight controls, good (but not obtrusive) storyline, and awesome gameplay. It's a must-play.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Shovel Knight is an homage to the golden age of gaming.  The style of overworld map is taken straight from Super Mario 3.  The gameplay feels like the best of both Castlevania and Mega Man.  It even has an element of Dark Souls, where dying causes Shovel Knight to drop gold that can recovered by returning to the spot where you died.  There are plenty of power-ups, upgrades, and secrets to acquire.  If retro platforming is your thing, you'll get everything you want from Shovel Knight.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												Honestly didn't know what to expect coming into this game, but I got instantly hooked the moment I started. Playing this game brought back a lot of fun memories I had of playing on the NES as a kid, from Ducktales to Mega Man. This game really captures the nostalgic feeling well while feeling fresh. My only regret is that I never got around to this game sooner.The controls in this game are really tight and responsive. I enjoy the fact that when I fail, it's my fault and not the fault of the game. The musical score is fantastic as well. A lot of really catchy pieces. And the sprite work is very well done. The designs and the animations are very well thought out and detailed. The level design as well is very well thought out. They do a great job at introducing mechanics and having you learn them before having you go out in challenges and master what you learned.I love how this game is set to where it's not too easy but not too hard, making it accessible to casual and hardcore gamers alike. Both campaigns were very enjoyable and I look forward to the Spectre Knight DLC which will be coming around soon as of this review. Definitely one of the most enjoyable, original platformers I had the joy of getting to play recently and if you haven't yet, I highly recommend giving this game a shot. Chances are, I'm sure you'll really DIG IT. :)

												I'm to lazy too truly think about and review this game, so I'll make this quick~It's a game where you play as a Knight and he kills things with a shovel. You collect gems and you can dig them out of the groud.If you feel really special, you can even use your shovel as a pogo stick, don't question it man.You can even kill other knights, because they're broke and don't have quarters. They can't even play an arcade machine, man.If you go to a town, you can get stuff. If the game is too hard, cheat. If it isn't then don't, 'cause that's stupid.I like this game, I'd dig it out in spades, but I suppose it depends what kind of hole you dig yourself into. I personally want to plow it right up. I like this game so much that I think about it every knight. I personally don't think they truly steel anything. You dig?Bad jokes aside, whether you like the NES style or not, you should still pick up this game. It takes every good game mechanic, refines them, and steels the NES art style and instruments. (Okay that's enough of the puns.)It's definately not something you should simply miss, I'll put it that way. Whether you like it or not is up to opinion, but you should at least try it.Also DLC is MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM goooooooooooooooooooooooood

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												A short review for the short time I've put in so far:The still images look like it could have come from an 8-bit machine. But in motion it's as smooth as it is pretty. The classic game mechanics makes for a smooth gaming experience. I've never experienced any slowdown from this game on my rather average spec. laptop. as is prone to happen occasionally in like 30-60% of the games I play on the machine.Playable on a two button controller which is a plus, although it would have been nice if some of the direction+button commands were mapped to the extra buttons on your average controller.The main melee attack is prehaps a bit on the short side. I found it easier to kill most enemies with the downward strike. And I find the loss of gold on death rather annoying, especially when they are floating somewhere inaccessable.A great game, but I doubt it will have me coming back anytime soon once I've completed it. That's why I'm taking my time with it, a location/upgrade unlocked every week or two.8.4/10

The healthy difficulty curve really contribute to this game's replayability, too. I can see myself in the future doing another run of this game for some good old fashioned fun.On a personal note, this is one of the few games that can make you feel emotions. Any time during the Shield Knight dream sequences, the music and overall theme did an excellent job at making you specifically go for Shield Knight. I missed her once on the third dream sequence and almost cried. Not to mention at the end of the game I felt tears welling up in my eyes when she was going to sacrifice herself to save you, then audibly cheered when it turned out she was alive.I haven't gotten that excited about a video game since I was eight years old when I first beat Ocarina of Time. No game has been able to capture that old fashioned sense of achievement since then for me. content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I would like to say that I am not a platformer kind of gamer. I prefer things like RPG's, Action/adventure, and FPS. I do not like games that are from the 16 bit era that much. I lived and played games during that time and I am honestly glad that time period is over. With that being said, I think Shovel Knight is an amazing game. I think the gameplay is solid. There are a bunch of collectables in it. Not to mention there is a tone of upgrades to Shovel Knight. The storyline is pretty predictable  but that is ok because the gameplay itself is fun. I like how there is an acheivement for listenining to all the puns that one character says in the game. I like that they put that character in the game. It ads an extra form of humor without the need for a storyline mission or a side quest. I like how there is a Mario style of map to move around in. I have to say, I was impressed by this game. I didn't think I was going to like it as much as I do. If you like retro style gaming then you need to have this one in your library. If you don't like those type of games then I still recommend this game because I don't like retro platformers and I still found this game to be fun and worth my time playing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Shovel Knight is quite different from many platformers in many senses. To begin the idea of using the shovel is interesting because it allows for more unique puzzles/treasures. Another interesting part of the game is the ability to press down to bounce on top of enemies with your shovel. The extent to which this can be used to grant you bonus treasures, defeat bosses, and even get more power ups makes it more than a gimmick, but turns it into a very important mechanic to learn and master. Furthermore, the game has some of the most creative bosses and stages of any game. Each stage has its own mechanics that you must be able to pick up on the fly. Normally I would not like this, but you are usually given one stage where you can practice using the mechanic before having to use it to complete a screen. Overall I highly recommend Shovel Knight.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												This game does something rare in that it not only captures the magnificent level designs, feel, gameplay and sound of Capcom games on the NES but it also manages to pick apart all of the fun elements and merge them into a finely tuned being, with its own identity and music worthy of a purchase. The game slowly hands you more difficult dishes until before long you're taking on swarms of enemies that used to give you a hard time when they were solo. The bosses, stages and items keep things interesting and the game never really gets stale. I'd recommend this game to anyone who has ever liked Megaman, Ducktales, or any other good platformer from the 8/16/32 bit eras.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Shovel Knight take me back to the days of playing Megaman and Mario. The game center around the hero Shovel Knight in his quest to stop the Enchantress and her evil knights of the Order of No Quarter. Shovel Knight plays like Super Mario Bros 3 and Megaman. By that I mean the overworld is just like the overworld of Super Mario Bros 3 where you on a overworld map and you select a stage to enter. And the levels play like a standard Megaman level where you must platform your way through, destroy enemies, and use items and power-ups you got along the way to help get to the end of stage where you will generally fight one of the knights of the Order of No Quarter.Now none of this bad, quite the opposite, it taking some of my favorite parts from those games and making a good game out of it. It definately add to the nostalgia factor for anyone who played those games. But this game is easily it own game with it fun story, colorful characters and bosses, and finally it has a fun soundtrack.This is a must get for anyone who think themselves a side scrolling platformer fan. And if this wasn't enough for you to get this, also know that the developers are releasing DLC that will add new characters and features to the game (this is because they reached their kick-starter reach goals). This a lot of great content for less than $15.Edit:Plague of Shadows add on to the Shovel Knight story by telling it from the side of one of the villains known as Plague Knight. Use Plague Knights bombs to blast your way through the levels. You can customize the bombs and rearrange the casing, powder, and fuse on the bomb. Each one of these affect how the bomb work and how you will use them. The level are almost identical to the one in Shovel Knight but with some slight differences to allow for Plague Knight to get through the level. One way this game shine is how it take side characters that you would have not given a second thought to an actual back story. I personal enjoy the interaction between Mona and Plague Knight.This was a welcome expansion to the game and the fact that it was free make it all the better.Edit 2: Specter of Torment add on is the prequel story telling how the Specter Knight recruited knights of no quarter join the Enchantress. As Specter Knight you must cut the other knights into submission to make them join the Enchantress. Specter Knight plays far differently than Plague Knight and Shovel knight. He can climb up walls and do slicing attack to enemy to zip his way up to higher areas. This style take a some getting use to but once you do it feel right. Like with the previous campaigns you will get items and armor that can make you game easier. I salute Yacht Club for their ability to take not only a boss character but every minor character and flesh their character and story out. Specter Knight campaign is full of minor characters who couldn't get their shine in the previous campaigns. With 2 campaigns done and a genderswap mode added, all that is left is the King Knight campaign.

content:
Posted: March 9
												While I prefer my fantasy with more dragons, this game has everything you could ask for in an action plateformer. lovely pixel art, a killer soundtrack and game elements and mechanics that were inspired by so many old classic games such as Super Mario 3's map system, megaman esque level designs and bosses, hidden items like in legend of zelda, and of course the pogo stick mechanic from Ducktales!Take up your shovel blade and get ready to fight all manner of warriors, worlocks and monsters. Like the classics all the mechanics are taught through experience instead of hand holding tutorials. The story is simple, yet it has one of the most epic plot twists ever. Sorry, no spoilers, you'll have to beat the game to find out.I also enjoy how the map enviroment is never stagnent, random encounters pop up all over the place, and the penalty system for dying is rather unique and fair. Instead of losing lives, you loose your gold, or jewels I guess.This game is worth every peny and more, ten out of ten I say. Now if you'll excuse me, I've treasure to dig up.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												This game is probably one of the best platformers I've ever played. Gameplay Shovel Knight plays in a similar way to a Megaman game, where you have to defeat all the knights of the order of no quarter (kind of like the robot masters in Megaman), and the levels are composed of "rooms". The level design is so well made, it teaches you brilliantly the mechanics of the game really quickly, and there are very few moments where you say to yourself "this is the game's fault", because usually every death is justified, the mechanics in one room were taught to you before hand so you know what to expect.  Plague of Shadows The Plague of Shadows update gives you (once you've cleared the game) the possibility to play as Plague Knight, one of the Knights of the Order of no quarter. The gameplay changes entirely, and you get to replay the entire game as a baddie. It's really fun and is a great addition to the game. The Story The story, while being simple, is pretty good in my opinion. You are Shovel Knight, an adventurer that used to roam the land with his partner, Shield Knight. They go exploring the Tower of Fate, where Shield Knight gets defeated and Shovel Knight is forced to escape. He then retires to a more peaceful life, but The Enchantress and her Order of no quarter start ruling the land. Shovel Knight, wanting to fight this evil, comes back and begins his quest to defeat The Enchantress. Plague of Shadows In the update, Plague Knight's quest is to brew a potion that will make him extremely powerful, but for that he will need the essence of every Knight of the Order of no Quarter, including The Enchantress' essence. With the help of Mona, your alchemist assistant, you begin your quest to defeat every knight and brew this strength potion. OST The OST. Oh man the OST. It is composed by the man, the legend, Jake Kaufman, and he just nails it once again. The soundtrack is really good and fits the overall feeling of the game extremely well. I don't think that Jake Kaufman could ever fail the soundtrack for a game. The soundtrack of Plague of Shadows is just as good. TL;DR I greatly recommend buying Shovel Knight. While it is not the longest game, it is still extremely fun to play and definitely worth it's price, the level design is incredibly well done, the controls feel really well, the OST is insanely good. Yacht Games' first title is a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												I've been playing this game on the Wii U, and have decided to get the PC version, so... here's my reviewPros:- Excellent Level Design, with well-made soundtrack- Very subtle throwbacks to retro games, like Ducktales, Zelda 2, and Super Mario Bros 3- Nice, tight controls, with a lack of bs game mechanics- Platforming is surprisingly well-madeCons:- Limited replayability- Relic system is a bit on the gimmicky side, especially as only one is universally useful.Shovel Knight is an excellent game with clever retro callbacks, with the more obvious references going to the likes of Ducktales. It's very easy to get accustomed to the game mechanics, and recognize patterns, and the levels kept me coming back. A Super Mario Bros 3-style map, filled with treasure levels, and roaming boss battles, helps to fill the retro vibe.The level design is very uniform, and the level is consisted of several checkpoints that you can break to get more treasure, at the expense of that checkpoint. I tended to break the middle checkpoints, and completely ignore the checkpoints that pop up right before a boss battle. Each level has a mix of variations of enemies, and level-unique enemies as well, so no complaints there. I also found that the soundtrack is very suiting for each level, giving each level a ice musical theme, further supplemented by the boss theme.Playing first with my keyboard, and then with a custom NES controller helped me understand that the controls are tight, a callback to Castlevania, which means fhat precision does in fact play a role in the game. There never really was a time where I felt the game cheated me out of a death, but rather, my error in understanding enemy patterns and mistakes in movement were the cause of my demise.One of my only gripes is that replayability is limited in this game. Sure, there's a New Game+ mode, and a DLC gamemode called Plague of Shadows, as well as a challenge mode, but overall, the replayability is limited in this game. The other gripe is the relic mechanic. In the game, you can access a room with a blue chest in each level, where you can spend a certain amount on a relic that can aid you in the game. I found that each level allowed for use with the accompanying relic, but one relic seemed to be too advantageous, and that was the phase locket, which grants brief invincibility to it's user.Overall, I really like this game. Sure, the replayability is limited, and some relics can be bs, but all in all, this is a game that bears little flaw, and those flaws are quickly outshone by the good parts of the game. 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												tl;dr: Even if you barely like pixel art games and or/platformers of any form, then give this game a try, it is that good!There are some very rare games which are just so good that it is hard to find anything bad about them. Shovel Knight is one of those games and it's just the first game from Indie developer Yacht Club Games. The game is a brilliant "modern oldschool" Action-Platformer that draws inspiration from many classic NES games like Castlevania, Duck Tales and mostly MegaMan but still feels very unique in its own way: Here you have 8 Boss Knights from the Order of No Quarter instead of 8 Robot Masters like you would have in  MegaMan including themed stages that look awesome and are bursting with collectibles, personality ( the character design is simply flawless) and innovative gameplay elements. And there are even more optional stages, towns to explore and enemy encounters on the map that looks a lot like the one from Super Mario Bros. 3. And that's just the tip of the iceberg: Nice Soundtrack, a whole lot more bosses than just the knights, armor and weapon upgrades, magic relics, dialogues and although there is a heavy focus on gameplay here as you might expect, a story that is at first very shallow, but gets unexpectedly touching for an 8-bit-game in the final stages . And fear not: The difficulty in the main game is really not that high, everybody should be able to complete normal mode. To those who seek a challenge, there is a much harder New Game + and some difficult achievements (Speedruns, No-Death-Runs etc.). I completed my first playthrough in about 8 hours and even if you just play through the game once, it's worth the fifteen bucks. So I totally recommend this game to anyone that doesn't hate the platforming genre, in fact I think that this game is the best release in 2014 till now.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												I don't think I need to go into a great deal of detail and praise for Shovel Knight. It's in no need of any more of that.I will say that Shovel Knight is a pleasant surprise compared to most indie games. It actually tries to improve upon a formula to a degree as opposed to forcing many design flaws from old games just because "that made the experience more difficult and more rewarding in those old games" according every retro loving geek ever. It's important to me that the game is difficult enough to be a challenge without being so difficult that I just refuse to pick it up again for weeks, but then I'm terrible at games (I'm not a filthy casual, I'm just bad) and I always have trouble with platformers especially (finish Cave Story for god's sake) but Shovel Knight is a game that I think any person could easily jump into, so long as they don't have a problem with the retro graphics.The gameplay is solid, even though it's really just Jump & Shoot Man without the shooting. Plenty of jumping though. If I can knock the game for anything it would probably be that every boss is designed to be dispatched in the exact same manner, which isn't entirely a bad thing, but it makes the relics seem a tad useless outside of a few points where they are almost required. The Phase Locket is the most useful relic in the game, a little too useful though, as it is easy to abuse.The soundtrack is pretty good. I mean it's chiptune but I've never had a problem with that. I don't make a fuss about most music that does not have lyrics. It's memorable and that's all that matters. You can get the soundtrack up on Jake Kaufman's bandcamp for name your own price, as well as an arranged version of the soundtrack.Overall I'd say this game is worth a try if you're looking for a little nostalgia trip, or even just a game that's easy to just sit down and play.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Shovel Knight is one of the finest and most polished platformers I've played in years. Even if you can't relate to the whole nostalgic NES/Famicom gaming scene, you SHOULD still give this game a try. Belonging to the platformer genre, Shovel Knight has lots of jumping; fortunately, the jumping mechanics are smooth and easy to plan, so leaping over the many pits of death shouldn't be too stressful. Ninety-nine percent of my deaths were entirely my fault, which is good! The visuals are colorful and very distinguishable, so things that LOOK like they're in the background will NEVER turn out to be weird platforms or obstacles. You'd be surprised by how important this small detail can be in old platformers.The plot is a simple "Defeat the eight big bosses and save the girl!" affair, the relatively short length of the game is remedied by the addicting allure of a more challenging "New Game+ Mode", and the soundtrack... Lordy, the SOUNDTRACK! I actually listen to quite a few of the standout tracks on their own, when I'm not playing the game. For $15 (that's like, what, a couple coffees at Starbucks?), Shovel Knight is practically a steal. Quite frankly, I dig this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												If you are a fan of the 8-bit era, this is a must purchase. Sales be damned! Shovel Knight is a pixel-art platformer which incorporates many of the unique mechanics from classic titles such as Duck Tales, Super Mario Bros 3 and Mega Man. The art design is gorgeous despite the market seemingly being littered lately with retro style platformers and the music by Kaufman and Matsumae brings all the chiptune goodness you could ask for. I doubt I've enjoyed a soundtrack this much since Scott Pilgrim. The difficulty sits on the moderate level. However, NG+ will probably be making you throw your shovel at times. The title also contains a bevy of unlockables and alternate characters to play as which ramps up the replayability factor. Basically, grab your shovel, dig up the remains of your wallet from the Steam Sale and BUY this game!

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												If you grew up in the 1980s and you loved Mega Man and Castlevania on the NES, then you'll be happy to know that Shovel Knight is their spiritual successor. You can ask virtually everyone I know IRL and they will tell you that I love picking out the flaws in things. So it is with rather a stunned feeling that I have to say: this game is mostly perfect.An amazing chiptune soundtrack, great characters and a story that's practical, beautiful quasi-8-bit graphics, and fantastically responsive controls pretty much sum up what the game is made of... But it's the obvious love and respect with which the developers crafted the game that really takes it over the top.You really owe it to yourself to play Shovel Knight if you've ever loved a platform adventure game in your life. Even if it's not on sale, it's well worth what it costs; and that's coming from a hardened Steam Sale hunter.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												It's a perfect tribute to some of the older retro games. This game has some challenging platforming, unique bossfights, and a soundtrack that truly complements every moment you spend in the game, whether you are in an intense battle, or simply walking through the village. The controls handle well, and are straightforward and aren't to difficult to master. As I stated before, this game does have parts in which you may find difficult, but the checkpoints throughout the level will help keep you from having to repeat parts, and allow you to feel accomplished after completing each level. With each death, you lose a portion of the gold that you've collected throughout the game. You can collect this gold back when you return to where you had died previously. In short, It is an amazing retro-style 2D platformer. Shovel Knight is a ton of fun, and is a must have to your library!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												This ended up being my favorite game of 2014. You would think that this is another 2D indie side scroller that will eventually end up on a humble bundle, but do not wait for it to go on sale. GET IT NOW. Shovel Knight is a charming love letter to classic NES games that feels fresh and fluid. The gameplay is tight and you will smile to yourself when you suddenly recall Megaman, Castlevania, and even Contra and Ninja Gaiden while playing. That being said, this is an original game with a surprisingly touching story as well. The soundtrack is memorable and will be on my regular music playlist rotation in 2015! I will absolutely replay this game and shoot for 100% while eagerly awaiting Shovel Knight II!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												To start off this review I would like to say that I have played a lot of platformers before this one so I know what a good platformer looks like and this game, is a good platformer.And Shovel Knight is an excellent platformer as it combines retro plaforming elements with some modern elements seen in many games today, mainly the colours. It also has a good story which most platformers don't have. The main thing I would have to say about this game is that it is a perfect blend of Megaman and Super Mario as it allows you to traverse a map and choose different levels (Like Mario) but there are bosses at the end of each of level and they all have different "elements" (much like Megaman). Also you have a weapon which is useful in a platformer. Another thing to say about the game is that you have not just 1 weapon, but you can collect a small arsenal of weapons which are all very useful in different situations. I genuinely cannot find anything bad to say about this game.In short, Shovel Knight is an amazing game which combines platforming with good story-telling and RPG elements. I would recommend this to anyone who likes old school platforming games.             10/10

												This is the perfect game if you want to increase your blood presure and shorten your life span,If you're terrible at platformers like me.Frustrating but at the same time ALOT of FUN, the devs did a good job of capturing the style of old NES/SNES games allthought i often wished they didn't use some of those very old school NES/SNES ideas, such as :Instant death spikes, instant death pits and the infamous knockback effect which always knocks you back into a nearby death pit.Thankfully the game has a fair amount of checkpoints in every level, so it's at least somewhat forgiving.In general, the game feels like you took a bunch of old classic NES game and mixed them together, games such as : MegaMan,Super Marios 3,Castlevania and Metroid.The soundtrack is also just pure frekin' gold, really love it.The game is not very hard at the start but as you keep playing the difficulty keeps getting higher and higher, the last three levels being almost pure hell for me, i actully had to buy a new keyboard because of this game since i managed to brake my space key(jump key) in half because of how many times i started hiting it out of frustration due to the Tower of Fate: Entrance level.It'll kick your♥♥♥♥♥ but you'll keep coming back  for more.It is a game that will often request from you to be 100% perfect in certain levels and/or specific parts of a level but as much as it might frustrate you at those times, you'll also love it since the general gameplay just feels good and is so much frekin' fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I will tell you my personal experience of the game instead of some "This was good and this was not"-kind of thing. First of all. I am twenty nine years old writing this. Some might wonder why a twenty nine year old play a platform game that might be more suited for an eleven year old? My brother wonders the same thing when he sees me playing these kind of games and I do too whenever I play a bad one in search of the good stuff.Thing is. I spent a lot of hours on plattformers growing up especially most of the Mega Man games. In more recent years I been trying to find games that gives me a certain feeling that some of the old games gave me. I re-found it in Mega Man X (SNES), Donkey Kong Country (SNES) and Shatterhand (NES) for example. But most games just bores me after some time because they miss that certain something and I rather return to games more suitable for my age.. Say Red Dead Redemption (PS3) or The Walking Dead (PS3 and PC).Shovel Knight is one of the very few games that has given me the feeling I got as a kid. Most new games which is built upon a old concept is either too easy or too hard. Often centers around being "fast" and have lots of enemies. I am not looking for a easy or hard game though. I'm looking for a good game and Shovel Knight is just that.When I started playing it first looked like an old DOS-game and then as a cheap Mega Man rip-off but very soon I realized it was more to this game than meets the eye. As the game developed I see a whole nods to games I love.. Golden Axe, Super Mario 3, Duck Tales and even Link 2.Between levels you choose for your own liking you can visit a town. Just as in Link 2. The difference? These towns are actually fun to walk into and is very well done.. Unlike those for Link 2. Man I hated those towns even as a kid haha. The characters you meet there actually has something useful to say and they can help you in ways that make the game easier and more enjoyable.The Mega Man references are all over the place but they are never just "Hey, let's put this Mega Man-thing here". No. They reconstructe the ideas and make them unique. The bosses for example. In Mega Man you mostly just learn a pattern and then most are stupidly easy. These bosses, while some are easy, are much smarter and have a bunch of attacks. I have finished the game and I not even sure I saw all their moves. They just don't stand taking hits either. Put them in a dangerous position and they will eventually get out of it.The level design is top notch. There are plenty enemies and it's the hasards that mostly kill you or offer a real challenge. You don't need to be a genius to "get" what you are supposed to do but it makes the whole experience more fun and the next scene is never too predictable. An overall great flow during the whole game.Unlike Mega Man some unexpected things happens to the map.. Think of the axe-men in Super Mario 3. But better and offers variation. There was a "what the f**k"-moment for me in the game. Even that is explained in a good way later on. The game isn't just a one way street either. As I watched the end credits there are stuff I actually missed in the game.. Which makes a replay a welcomed experience.So... Nothing bad to say? Well. The game is very slow... Still better than too fast. But it could have been a notch faster. And I saw myself fighting against the controls.. Those who played Duck Tales and Darkwing Duck (NES) knows what I am talking about.In the end of the day the music drives the game forward, the level design is fantastic, the story is well done, the bosses are fun and while it reminds me of different games it still finds originality in a way most platform games don't.To me this is right up there with all the classics in the genre. Very well done guys. Comes recommended. I'd love to see more games with a similar concept that is as well done. I'd buy that. You should too!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												I don't think I need to go into a great deal of detail and praise for Shovel Knight. It's in no need of any more of that.I will say that Shovel Knight is a pleasant surprise compared to most indie games. It actually tries to improve upon a formula to a degree as opposed to forcing many design flaws from old games just because "that made the experience more difficult and more rewarding in those old games" according every retro loving geek ever. It's important to me that the game is difficult enough to be a challenge without being so difficult that I just refuse to pick it up again for weeks, but then I'm terrible at games (I'm not a filthy casual, I'm just bad) and I always have trouble with platformers especially (finish Cave Story for god's sake) but Shovel Knight is a game that I think any person could easily jump into, so long as they don't have a problem with the retro graphics.The gameplay is solid, even though it's really just Jump & Shoot Man without the shooting. Plenty of jumping though. If I can knock the game for anything it would probably be that every boss is designed to be dispatched in the exact same manner, which isn't entirely a bad thing, but it makes the relics seem a tad useless outside of a few points where they are almost required. The Phase Locket is the most useful relic in the game, a little too useful though, as it is easy to abuse.The soundtrack is pretty good. I mean it's chiptune but I've never had a problem with that. I don't make a fuss about most music that does not have lyrics. It's memorable and that's all that matters. You can get the soundtrack up on Jake Kaufman's bandcamp for name your own price, as well as an arranged version of the soundtrack.Overall I'd say this game is worth a try if you're looking for a little nostalgia trip, or even just a game that's easy to just sit down and play.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I would like to say that I am not a platformer kind of gamer. I prefer things like RPG's, Action/adventure, and FPS. I do not like games that are from the 16 bit era that much. I lived and played games during that time and I am honestly glad that time period is over. With that being said, I think Shovel Knight is an amazing game. I think the gameplay is solid. There are a bunch of collectables in it. Not to mention there is a tone of upgrades to Shovel Knight. The storyline is pretty predictable  but that is ok because the gameplay itself is fun. I like how there is an acheivement for listenining to all the puns that one character says in the game. I like that they put that character in the game. It ads an extra form of humor without the need for a storyline mission or a side quest. I like how there is a Mario style of map to move around in. I have to say, I was impressed by this game. I didn't think I was going to like it as much as I do. If you like retro style gaming then you need to have this one in your library. If you don't like those type of games then I still recommend this game because I don't like retro platformers and I still found this game to be fun and worth my time playing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Shovel Knight is quite different from many platformers in many senses. To begin the idea of using the shovel is interesting because it allows for more unique puzzles/treasures. Another interesting part of the game is the ability to press down to bounce on top of enemies with your shovel. The extent to which this can be used to grant you bonus treasures, defeat bosses, and even get more power ups makes it more than a gimmick, but turns it into a very important mechanic to learn and master. Furthermore, the game has some of the most creative bosses and stages of any game. Each stage has its own mechanics that you must be able to pick up on the fly. Normally I would not like this, but you are usually given one stage where you can practice using the mechanic before having to use it to complete a screen. Overall I highly recommend Shovel Knight.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												If you grew up in the 1980s and you loved Mega Man and Castlevania on the NES, then you'll be happy to know that Shovel Knight is their spiritual successor. You can ask virtually everyone I know IRL and they will tell you that I love picking out the flaws in things. So it is with rather a stunned feeling that I have to say: this game is mostly perfect.An amazing chiptune soundtrack, great characters and a story that's practical, beautiful quasi-8-bit graphics, and fantastically responsive controls pretty much sum up what the game is made of... But it's the obvious love and respect with which the developers crafted the game that really takes it over the top.You really owe it to yourself to play Shovel Knight if you've ever loved a platform adventure game in your life. Even if it's not on sale, it's well worth what it costs; and that's coming from a hardened Steam Sale hunter.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												It's a perfect tribute to some of the older retro games. This game has some challenging platforming, unique bossfights, and a soundtrack that truly complements every moment you spend in the game, whether you are in an intense battle, or simply walking through the village. The controls handle well, and are straightforward and aren't to difficult to master. As I stated before, this game does have parts in which you may find difficult, but the checkpoints throughout the level will help keep you from having to repeat parts, and allow you to feel accomplished after completing each level. With each death, you lose a portion of the gold that you've collected throughout the game. You can collect this gold back when you return to where you had died previously. In short, It is an amazing retro-style 2D platformer. Shovel Knight is a ton of fun, and is a must have to your library!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												If you liked challenging NES platformers such as Castlevania, Megaman, and Zelda 2, you'll enjoy Shovel Knight. It's quite challenging, but there are plenty of checkpoints throughout the levels, and you get infinite lives, so as to keep frustration levels low.The levels are designed intelligently, in that new game mechanics are gradually introduced - you might learn how to deal with bouncy squid on one screen, and then on the next screen you'll have to bounce on the squid to get over some spikes.The music is excellent in chiptune style, reminiscent of the NES games I mentioned earlier. There also seem to be references to Megaman and other games - for instance there is a boss who resembles Enker from the Megaman series in terms of his attacks.Overall, this is a well made game which is quite challenging, but not too frustratingly impossible.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												A lot of people seem to think of this game as the Messiah of all games - The peak of what we're capable of achieving. This has led to this game acquiring a somewhat over-the-top amount of praise.Is the game good? Yes! Is it great? Yeah.. Is it the best thing ever? Not quite.Let's be reasonable here: It's a fun retro-platformer offering a lot of challenge and bringing back a lot of mechanics from older titles that we haven't seen used in a larger and more popular mainstream title for a long time. Please, do keep in mind that some of these mechanics were left behind for a reason though.It's a good, fun game - Possibly even close to a masterpiece, but it is *not* 'the one game to rule them all'.What does it do really well?- Tight controls and Dualshock 4 compatibility without any outside tools needed.- Even thought it's an old style, the visuals are nice if you enjoy pixel-art.- A good sense of humor and a decent, if slightly confusing, story.- It's got a great deal of content and, like most games in this genre, it's more or less infinitely replayable. What does it do not-so-well?- An absolutely minute amount of bugs that can ruin your day. These are extremely rare in my experience, but while the game is solid it's not bulletproof.- Some of the mechanics are.. Well, not so fun. Rooms going completely dark, forcing you to go around not really sure of where you're going or what's up above or beneath you. Bosses that have a slightly tiresome amount of RNG and lack of control to them leading to some not always very fair deaths. Mechanics that take control away from the player and leaves you relying on luck more than skill, and some screens where a you run the possible risk of getting a setup of hazards that's unpassable. (It's rare, but it happens, and it basically means a reset/death.)I'd recommend this game to any platform enthusiast, but at the same time.. If you're like me and don't like mechanics where you can't rely on skill, this game *will* frustrate you every now and again. The difficulty curve towards the end also takes a rather sudden, massive leap, making the second half of the game far, far harder than the first half without really easing you into it.Great game, definitely a classic, and something I'm going to play more of - It's not the best game I've ever seen, nor evne the best of this particular genre. Top 5, but not number 1.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												This game is incredible. Shovel Knight is a game about a knight, clad in cerulean armor, with a shovel for a weapon. He used to roam the lands with his love, until they were seperated at the Tower of Fate. Now, Shovel Knight must rise up once more to protect the valley from the Order of No Quarter.This game is super freaking hard. Maybe it's just because I suck, but this game is difficult. You will ragequit. You will swear at it. But at the end of the game, you will love it. It's a combination of tons of different NES games. It has the pogo-jump from Ducktales, the knockback effect from Castlevania, and the boss battles and instakill spikes from MegaMan. If you loved those games, you will love this. I died a total of about 100 times. No joke, no sarcasm. 100 times. I think maybe a little more. That's how hard this game is. If you're not a fan of constantly dying, you will not like this game. If you don't like gorgeous 8-bit graphics and incredible chiptune songs, you will also not like this song. But if you put aside the "terrible" graphics and the "♥♥♥♥♥♥" music, you will discover an incredible experience.Plus, there's a new free expansion for the game, and another coming up, that lets you play as Plague Knight and Spectre Knight, so there's a pretty good replayablity to it.9.5/10I don't like dying.TL:DR: It's difficult, but good. Buy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I just finished the game for the first time and I really enjoyed it. In total I died 137 times, and each time I take full responsibility for. I don't play this type of game very often but at no point did I feel like the game cheated me. I played the entirety of it with a DualShock 4 controller and it handled perfectly with the DS4Windows program. I purchased the soundtrack+game bundle because the soundtrack is really that good. Each zone has a great theme and the song for each is memorable, with "Strike the Earth!" being my favorite. Most of the bosses are interesting and challenging, I think I only one-shot one of them. The strategies to beat them aren't rocket science and defeating them is only a matter of execution. The final boss sequence is particularly rewarding and unique. The biggest surprise for me was the world of the game. There are genuinely funny moments and characters and by the end of the game you really feel for the main character. I highly recommend playing this if you like well-made platformers.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												(My Original Review) - October 2014This game... I just can't put into proper words to describe how great it is...For such a short game, it left a impact on me, and not just nostalgically.I've had so many great moments with this game that I can say right now it's a MUST play for sure! I'm happy to say, its now a new member to my family of top 10 favorite video games of all time. But enough about me and my experience with the game, after all its no fun listening to someone ramble on about it, but thats what Shovel Knight kinda does to you. I've become so attached to this gemstone of a game over the past year that I kinda find myself lost within' it on every new playthrough.With all the charm it put into it's characters, and all the effort, love and the sheer polish of its platforming. And the soundtrack, good lord, the soundtrack! It's pure bliss without the ignorance and it does it so effortlessly.Go play it and you'll see what I'm talking about. If you're a either a die-hard nostalgic platform lover, or a casual player of games, it deserves your attention.UPDATE: (Plague of Shadows DLC) - December 2016As this game continues to grow and show off more about the other knights and their stories, it still stands to prove it's mark on my words. Plague of Shadows is Yacht Club's love letter to the community that still continues to support them in anyway possible. THIS IS HOW YOU MAKE GOOD DLC PEOPLE! Having the choice to play as another knight aside from Shovel Knight, and playing a completely altered main-story campaign to the one you're used to, is in a level of its own of how much the developers care about their game and the people who play their game.Taking control of Plague Knight (the main protagonist of the Plague of Shadows DLC) is completely different from the way you play the cyan-ironclad digger himself. Taking place during the same time as Shovel Knight's quest (and even intertwining with each other), Plague Knight comes equipped with his own tools for alchemical anarchy and mayhem. Concoct and brew your own bombs with the many of different effects at your reach to dispose of your enemies in droves of pretty explosions. How he moves, attacks and even jumps is so unique as oppose to Shovel Knight hes literaly a different character all his own. While tricky to get used to at first, once you get the hang of him you may find yourself not going back to Shovel Knight once you've played around with Plague Knight and all his marvelous gadgets.While also having an altered version of the main campaign, the story of both knights is just as diverse as they are from each other. However I won't spoil anything of Plague Knight's story as that should be experienced on your own terms to get the full enjoyment of it. But while saying so, the story will come and suprise you and twist any previous relationships with this beaked villian of the Order of No Quarter.And do you want to know the best part about this DLC, aside from offering an alternate story and new character to play?... IT'S FREE! It all comes with the full game, so is it really considered DLC anymore? Well yes and no. Its more of an addition to the full game that came in a update to it rather than being side content that you would pay extra money for. But hey, thats a good thing! This means you get basically get a semi-prequel and you don't have to pay the extra money (even though I would of payed money for this sort of thing. C'mon Yacht Club just take our money already).And so, as was said before about the original, this is a instant classic among myself and others who have played it. If you haven't gotten the chance to buy it yet, I still recommend it to anybody! And I can't wait to write another review about the next upcoming DLC, Specter of Torment, featuring Specter Knight.

												I just finished the game for the first time and I really enjoyed it. In total I died 137 times, and each time I take full responsibility for. I don't play this type of game very often but at no point did I feel like the game cheated me. I played the entirety of it with a DualShock 4 controller and it handled perfectly with the DS4Windows program. I purchased the soundtrack+game bundle because the soundtrack is really that good. Each zone has a great theme and the song for each is memorable, with "Strike the Earth!" being my favorite. Most of the bosses are interesting and challenging, I think I only one-shot one of them. The strategies to beat them aren't rocket science and defeating them is only a matter of execution. The final boss sequence is particularly rewarding and unique. The biggest surprise for me was the world of the game. There are genuinely funny moments and characters and by the end of the game you really feel for the main character. I highly recommend playing this if you like well-made platformers.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												(My Original Review) - October 2014This game... I just can't put into proper words to describe how great it is...For such a short game, it left a impact on me, and not just nostalgically.I've had so many great moments with this game that I can say right now it's a MUST play for sure! I'm happy to say, its now a new member to my family of top 10 favorite video games of all time. But enough about me and my experience with the game, after all its no fun listening to someone ramble on about it, but thats what Shovel Knight kinda does to you. I've become so attached to this gemstone of a game over the past year that I kinda find myself lost within' it on every new playthrough.With all the charm it put into it's characters, and all the effort, love and the sheer polish of its platforming. And the soundtrack, good lord, the soundtrack! It's pure bliss without the ignorance and it does it so effortlessly.Go play it and you'll see what I'm talking about. If you're a either a die-hard nostalgic platform lover, or a casual player of games, it deserves your attention.UPDATE: (Plague of Shadows DLC) - December 2016As this game continues to grow and show off more about the other knights and their stories, it still stands to prove it's mark on my words. Plague of Shadows is Yacht Club's love letter to the community that still continues to support them in anyway possible. THIS IS HOW YOU MAKE GOOD DLC PEOPLE! Having the choice to play as another knight aside from Shovel Knight, and playing a completely altered main-story campaign to the one you're used to, is in a level of its own of how much the developers care about their game and the people who play their game.Taking control of Plague Knight (the main protagonist of the Plague of Shadows DLC) is completely different from the way you play the cyan-ironclad digger himself. Taking place during the same time as Shovel Knight's quest (and even intertwining with each other), Plague Knight comes equipped with his own tools for alchemical anarchy and mayhem. Concoct and brew your own bombs with the many of different effects at your reach to dispose of your enemies in droves of pretty explosions. How he moves, attacks and even jumps is so unique as oppose to Shovel Knight hes literaly a different character all his own. While tricky to get used to at first, once you get the hang of him you may find yourself not going back to Shovel Knight once you've played around with Plague Knight and all his marvelous gadgets.While also having an altered version of the main campaign, the story of both knights is just as diverse as they are from each other. However I won't spoil anything of Plague Knight's story as that should be experienced on your own terms to get the full enjoyment of it. But while saying so, the story will come and suprise you and twist any previous relationships with this beaked villian of the Order of No Quarter.And do you want to know the best part about this DLC, aside from offering an alternate story and new character to play?... IT'S FREE! It all comes with the full game, so is it really considered DLC anymore? Well yes and no. Its more of an addition to the full game that came in a update to it rather than being side content that you would pay extra money for. But hey, thats a good thing! This means you get basically get a semi-prequel and you don't have to pay the extra money (even though I would of payed money for this sort of thing. C'mon Yacht Club just take our money already).And so, as was said before about the original, this is a instant classic among myself and others who have played it. If you haven't gotten the chance to buy it yet, I still recommend it to anybody! And I can't wait to write another review about the next upcoming DLC, Specter of Torment, featuring Specter Knight.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Kickstarter gets a bad rap sometimes, and for good reason, but if the service creates more games like this, I will die defending it, because Shovel Knight is one of the finest platformers I have ever played. The market is flooded with mediocre retro-style indie platformers that do little more than pander to people's nostalgia for a quick buck, but Shovel Knight stands out as a game that truly feels like an 8-bit game, from the color palatte to the sound design to the two-button control scheme, and would stand tall as a classic even alongside 8-bit titans like Mega Man and Castlevania. Controls are tight and fluid, giving you perfect control and making the simple actions you perform fun in their own right, which is essential for a platformer. The level design in on par with the best of the NES era, teaching the player about it's mechanics without ever shoving it in their face, and offering some amazingly creative ideas and mechanics. The combat is very fun, with several oppurtunities to test your shoveling skills against enemies that take more than one hit to fell, allowing you to chain attacks together in a smooth and satisfying fashion. The boss battles in particular are fantastic, offering massive challenge and forcing you to think on your feet, since they have set attacks, but don't always do those attacks in the same order. They're the best bosses I've ever seen in a 2D platformer. Despite it's purposeful limitations, the game looks great, and the music is some of the best chiptune work I've ever heard. It even has a story, and a good one at that, with some great interactive storytelling and a genuinely touching ending. It's no masterpiece, but it's more than I'd expect from a game like this, especially when so many higher-budget games with more focus on story get it so wrong.What impresses me most about Shovel Knight, though, is how well it captures the true essenece of nostalgia. Most retro indie games' defintion of nostalgia is to say "hey, remember game X? Wasn't game X great?" which is misguided admiration at best and manipulative design at worst. Instead, Shovel Knight builds the elements that create nostalgia into the core of it's design, rather than merely reminding us of games that incited those same feelings. It does this through a combination of discovery and safety. Shovel Knight, while playing on familiar tropes, has many incredibly unique and surprising moments that play with our expectations to create something new, and even when they're not setting us up the level and mechanic design is so utterly inspired you just can't help but be in awe of it. However, there isn't too much new. The game is presented in a style familar to nearly everyone who plays games, and the simple traditions that underscore this discovery, like returning to the town to give music sheets to the bard and buy health upgrades, give the game a safe haven, a sense of security that prevents the influx of new mechanics from becoming overwhelming and threatening. Discovery and security are the things that made childhood great: being able to experience so many things for the first time, but always having a sense of security in the feeling that you would come inside and mom would cook you dinner at the end of the day. So in other words, Shovel Knight evokes emotions that reflect a positive view of childhood, and what word describes a positive view of the past? Nostalgia. People often use nostalgia as a negative, but they have to realize that for a game to invoke nostalgia, the memories of it have to be positive. The same techniques that make people remember games like Zelda so fondly are replicated perfectly in Shovel Knight, and that is no small feat.Admittedly, the game isn't perfect. The biggest problem is that it's a bit on the easy side. Checkpoints are frequent, magic items are too powerful, and magic refills are far too common. While this does suit the game's intent, which is more about having simple fun than massive challenges, it left me wanting more when I completed the quest. The New Game + mode does address these problems by increasing damage, removing health power-ups, and giving you less checkpoints, but it would have been nice if that was selectable from the start as hard difficulty. Additionally, there isn't nearly enough to spend your money on, and all the treasure you get from the pleathora of well-hidden secrets this game doesn't take long to become worthless. Finally, there's a bit too much knockback for my liking, as I fell into several pits simply by being knocked into them by an enemy. The overarching theme of this game seems to be to take the good bits of retro games and leave the bad stuff behind, so it's inclusion is perplexing and occasionally frustrating. There is an armor which reduces knockback, though, which I like. Also, the game is kind of short, though a short length suits this kind of game. Overall, though, these are just nitpicks. Shovel Knight is an amazingly fun. It's a spectacular experience that anyone who enjoys the classics of the NES era will love, and even if you don't, Shovel Knight may convince you that, despite their age, those old games still have a lot of merit, and the love people have for them shouldn't be dismissed as a rose-tinted view of the past and a resistance to change, but rather a celebration of everything those old games did so right that newer titles have forgotten.9/10P.S. If you want a true challenge out of Shovel Knight, the best way to do it is to try and speedrun the game. This game was made with speedrunning in mind, and it's increcdibly fun and accessible to try and see how fast you can blaze through the game. It's truly where the game comes into it's own, and the mastery of all the items and mechanics becomes neccesary and the brilliant design becomes apparent. It's something you have to experience, even if you're normally turned off by the idea of speedrunning.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												After playing the game for 2 hours or so, here are my thoughts:The developers behind this game "get" what makes a good 2D platform actually GOOD.+ Responsive controls+ Stages with diverse hazards in accordance to their theme+ Memorable boss fights+ Awesome musicOn top of this, they added:+ A checkpoint system that is both good for beginners and experts alike (for different reasons)+ Instead of having a finite amount of tries before you get kicked out of a long stage, you lose an amount of your wealth that is retrievable, if you can reach the screen where you died (think Dark Souls)+ Towns, vendors, minigames, sidequests, upgradable armor and special movesMy only "problem" so far is that with a system that offers you an infinite amount of retries and a very forgiving checkpoint system, they decided to add refillable potions that top up your health and mana to the max and some other stuff that are fairly OP (IMHO, always).But, given that the developers intended the game to be accessible to beginners and experts alike, the latter can freely choose not to use them (there are also achievements if you don't die at all, break all the checkpoints in the game, don't buy anything with money etc. so for people who crave to be challenged there are plentiful of ways to get their fix).There's also official word for free content released at a later date such as challenge mode, gender reverse mode, battle mode with the order of no quarter and 3 playable boss campaigns.tl;dr Just buy it already!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Shovel Knight is a game brought to us by ex devs working at Wayforward games who want to bring back the nostalgic feels of the old NES/SNES days. But will they succeed or fail miserably ? We play as Shovel Knight. He and Shield Knight were the most heroic knights in the land but one day after Shield Knight dissapears Shovel Knight stops fighting evil. But one day an Evil witch named the enchantress takes over the land and its up to you to stop her Knights and herself before she destroys the land. So how is Shovel Knight ? This game is exceptional and without a doubt this is a game you need to have in youre steam library no matter what. The gameplay is mixed into diffrent things. You can use youre shovel to dig secret places so you can find gold which you can use to buy upgrades and magic relics. You can also use it like a pogo to jump on enemies in the vein of Ducktales the video game. The game also has very tight controls so whenever you die its youre fault entirely. The game also looks absolutly beutifull and its one of the best games on steam as of now. The game also has a very catchy soundtrack and its a delight to listen while you fight enemies and conquer bosses. Overall theres not too much bad to say about Shovel Knight. The game has a few minor bugs but thats pretty much it. The game is tough so expect a challenge. Overall Shovel Knight is an exceptional game which you simply need to own no matter what cause its that good. I give Shovel Knight a 10/10 ( Yeah Its that good)

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												This is not your average shovel-ware retro indie game. (You heard me.) I bought it this evening and immediately put 3.5 hours into it simply because I couldn't put it down. I'm a huge fan of classic Mega Man, and this is on the same level except much less mash-heavy which is definitely a plus and with some RPG-elements added. Basically it's a classic melee/precision platformer with plenty of interesting and novel mechanics as well as loads of humor. Also checkpoints a-plenty throughout the levels which helps if you're impatient and/or maybe not too experienced with platformers. I wouldn't call it unforgiving --- not at all --- but it certainly expects you to actually put an effort into beating it. ('It' = the game. Yeah, I know what you were thinking.)The game rarely (if ever) kills you in cheap ways --- you're pretty much always the one to blame which is also why, if you're easily frustrated by challenging platforming, you'll probably want to skip this game. However, if you dig great platforming experiences, hilarious puns, and the sweet sweet taste of victory when killing bosses, then you'll love this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												“Justice in spades!”	Such is the rallying cry of the brave warrior Shovel Knight, who adventures across the land to defeat the Enchantress, who has conquered this once-peaceful land.  I’ve been looking forward to Shovel Knight, and there has been a lot of hype about it, particularly surrounding its many delays.  However, the wait was well worth it, and Shovel Knight is the pixel-styled side-scrolling platformer of your dreams.	The gameplay is smooth and I haven’t once felt cheated when questing through the world, defeating rats on propellers and strange spiders that ooze purple projectiles.  The game is very easy to learn, although the further you get into a level the trickier things will become.   One important thing to note about this game is the choice of controller.  I’m sure many people are fearful that their controller, whatever it may be, won’t be appropriate for this game.  Don’t worry, I’ve been playing with an Xbox 360 controller with a USB connection, and everything is fine.  The controls don’t lag, or feel buggy.  Shovel Knight moves in the direction I hold, and he turns and stops just fine.  A retro controller such as a USB super Nintendo controller may give you a nicer feel, because you’ll only be using three buttons, but choice of controller shouldn’t be a major issue.	Shovel Knight is, as I mentioned before, a side-scrolling 2d platformer game.  It has all of your favorite elements- enemies flash and are knocked back with invincibility frames briefly when struck, as is Shovel Knight.  There is only one attack button, and one jump button.  Shovel Knight can also perform a downward shovel attack while jumping that is very important for reaching the game’s numerous hidden areas- you must use the limited supply of enemies or objects to bounce ever-higher, soaring distances that your jump button could never handle by itself.  There are also items, called Relics, that you can gather and use.  This is the first place where I felt that the game balance might be a wee bit off- the Phase Amulet.	Once the Phase Amulet is in your possession, you may never want to use another relic.  It activates with no delay, and makes you invulnerable but still able to attack for about 2 seconds.  My first thought when I saw this item was, ‘This is incredibly overpowered.’ You can push the button to dodge any attack, survive environmental hazards, and generally shrug off anything.  That said, as the game progressed a bit more, I found that I was still dying, being hit, and generally not being able to instantly win.  Mana is a restriction that doesn’t come into play very often with this item, but simply being able to use it in time or being able to foresee an enemy’s attack is.  After spending some more time with the Phase Amulet, I think that it fits in quite well, and I mostly use it to dodge some bosses’ more irritating attacks.	The music in this game is top-notch, and every level will afford you a chance to find the Bard’s missing musical notes, enabling you to listen to whatever area’s theme you wish should you collect it.  My particular favorite so far is the theme from Pridemoor Keep, where you face King Knight, a jumpy golden ponce who attacks you with confetti and solid-gold armor.	My overall impression of Shovel Knight is joyous glee.  I haven’t enjoyed playing a game this much in quite a long time, and it’s really made an impression on me.  I would absolutely recommend this to any fan of the genre- keep in mind that this is a new game designed to look and feel like an old game, and it succeeds at that in spades.

												Please play this game. If you ever enjoyed any platformer you ever played on a Nintendo or Super Nintendo, you'll love this one. It takes everything that was learned from those eras and makes the best game it can out of it. Its a mostly lighthearted game light on story as well but the minimal characterization and plot is still very effective. Its like coming home again and finding that home is how you remember it in your fondest recollections. Its like you're having a sleepover with your buddies eating pizza and washing it down with wine playing games all night and somehow its not weird that you're 40. Its like the best of the past of the present.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												You need this game. Shovel Knight is the perfect game with no flaws. It takes all the greatest features from classic games such as Castlevania, Mega Man, Zelda 2: The Adventure of Link, Super Mario Bros. 3, and DuckTales all combined into one. The game is tough but never too hard. It's challenging but forgiving. The game always rewards you after every challenge that crosses you path. Also we must not forget about the soundtrack. Jake Kaufman accels in all audio departments and makes this soundtrack timeless. Yacht Club Games is still adding more to this game makeing it more enjoyable than it already is and with the amount of content that is already in the game, you'll never want to put the controller down. I don't know a single person that hates this game and you owe it to yourself to play it. Buy it, For Shovelry. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Shovel Knight is a tough but fair retro style action platformer that mixes the 8-bit style of Mega Man and Ducktales but utilizes modern game design and processing power. It'll kick your butt a few times and test your skill. It cleverly uses a D-pad and 4 button control scheme, so you can use a USB adapter for an NES controller, and the game is a very rewarding experience that way. I don't know of anything on Steam that does this. Also, the music is another great job by Virt, Lich Yard and The Lost City themes being favorites, and the humor is top notch. Recommended if you're old enough to remember the Clinton administration.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												My first time playing through took my 6.5 hours, and apparently I had an 86% "item completion" despite my having all relics, armor, and shovel upgrades.  Despite that bit of weirdness, I had a very enjoyable time with Shovel Knight.  The story is cutesy, and gets a bit weird at the end.  Controls are great.  Hitboxes are a little too wide, but once you get the hang of it you learn to be okay with it.  Shovel Knight does EVERYTHING it sets out to do, and does it really well. Music is fantastic, graphics are engaging, mechanics (jump/slash/bounce) feel really good and responsive.I would recommend to anyone playing on a controller to set the relic use to the Right Bumper, though.  I realize why the default is set to X+Up, to accommodate the NES theme of 2-buttons-&-a-D-Pad, but it just doesn't work.Anyhow, I am done rambling.  This game is very easily worth the $15 just for the regular campaign.  New Game + and speed-running give it a ton more value.Enjoy!

												You don't have to dig too deep to know that Shovel Knight is one gem worth buying.  The difficulty climbs at a steady pace; you don't have to shovel down too much at once.  Some games bury you in tutorials wereas Shovel Knight's gameplay teaches you as you go.  Music is the next item I'll unearth- 'Strike the Earth' was absolutely ground breaking for me. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Now that I've finished the game, I can give it a full review.Shovel Knight is that perfect kind of homage to the games you played on the NES. There's a little DuckTales, a little Megaman, a little Zelda II, and even a little Mario 3. Heck, there's even a little bit of Dark Souls thrown in for good measure. The one thing I do want to immediately draw attention to is the level design. I can sum it up in just one word, "perfection". For the first time in a long time, I found myself learning the game's mechanics without the aid of a tutorial level, and considering the number of games out there that hold your hand through 75% of the game? I find it very refreshing.I love the music, and considering the composer worked on Contra 4 and Double Dragon Neon, I'm not surprised that it is some of the best. Add in some compositions from a classic Megaman composer, and you have yourself a soundtrack made of pure gold.In lieu of lives, death takes away some of your gold. You have one life to get that gold back or it is gone forever. This mechanic is very much like dying in Dark Souls, where your souls are taken away and you have one life to get them back.I felt tthat the game's length was just enough. I'm really looking forward to the additional modes coming in free updates later this year, but for now, I have enough to keep me busy. I feel like the 14.99 price tag is worth it overall.I have enjoyed my time with Shovel Knight, and I can honestly say, that it never was unfair. Any deaths were because of my own mistakes.For a first game, Yacht Club Games really knocked it out of the park. I hope to see a sequel someday, but I couldn't be happier to just have this game in my steam library. Proud to be a backer!I dig it!

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												If you grew up with the SNES or Sega Genesis you're going to love this modern throwback to the 16-Bit era. The gameplay is a lot like Super Mario meets Mega Man, with an original and enjoyable soundtrack, a healthy dose of comedy and a whole lot of action, this game will keep you on the edge of your seat. It's a bit of a challenge, and you'll probably die quite a bit but it's a great reminder that games don't need to be easy to be fun. However If you grew up with 3D graphics and that's all you want in a video game, this game is not for you....... (also ♥♥♥♥ you)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												This title is fully dedicated to being a nostalgia-fest, while bringing new flair and finesse to the platformer genre.  A love-child to gaming of generations' past, taking a mishmash of elements from the tried and true classics to some more obscure titles. Elements range from Mario 3 to Duck Tales to Mega Man and Castlevania. A stellar soundtrack, striking visuals, an overall good feel. The controls are fluid, and the level design is challenging without being unfair, leading to most deaths being a result of poor player judgement. tl;dr I dig it.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												As someone who loved playing Mega Man, Zelda, Castlevania, Duck Tales...etc, as a kid in the late 1980's, Shovel Knight is an absolute treasure for me to play. The graphics are great, the gameplay is tight/fun, and the music....the chiptune soundtrack is out of this world! As soon as I started playing I had to pause it and find the official soundtrack to "buy" (pay what you want) from Jake Kaufman's BandCamp page.If you are a fan of the old NES games I referenced above, this is a MUST BUY!I do hope to see more games coming from Yacht Club Games in the future.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Now that I've finished the game, I can give it a full review.Shovel Knight is that perfect kind of homage to the games you played on the NES. There's a little DuckTales, a little Megaman, a little Zelda II, and even a little Mario 3. Heck, there's even a little bit of Dark Souls thrown in for good measure. The one thing I do want to immediately draw attention to is the level design. I can sum it up in just one word, "perfection". For the first time in a long time, I found myself learning the game's mechanics without the aid of a tutorial level, and considering the number of games out there that hold your hand through 75% of the game? I find it very refreshing.I love the music, and considering the composer worked on Contra 4 and Double Dragon Neon, I'm not surprised that it is some of the best. Add in some compositions from a classic Megaman composer, and you have yourself a soundtrack made of pure gold.In lieu of lives, death takes away some of your gold. You have one life to get that gold back or it is gone forever. This mechanic is very much like dying in Dark Souls, where your souls are taken away and you have one life to get them back.I felt tthat the game's length was just enough. I'm really looking forward to the additional modes coming in free updates later this year, but for now, I have enough to keep me busy. I feel like the 14.99 price tag is worth it overall.I have enjoyed my time with Shovel Knight, and I can honestly say, that it never was unfair. Any deaths were because of my own mistakes.For a first game, Yacht Club Games really knocked it out of the park. I hope to see a sequel someday, but I couldn't be happier to just have this game in my steam library. Proud to be a backer!I dig it!
